title: Best movies about choosing your kids vs. career/self-realization/world-saving?
body:
I was thinking about this when I saw Interstellar. What a cosmic gut-punch, seeing McConaughey >!trapped in the fifth dimension, screaming to himself to stay with his daughter instead of going on a potentially Earth-saving mission!<. You could see the movie as a reckoning with traditional masculinity, I think. McConaughey's daughter is his everything, his little soulmate. Yet he leaves her to go on this mission. To go work for NASA. And it's not only for altruistic reasons; he feels useless just working as a farmer, being a trained space pilot stuck on ground.

I loved 80% of the movie. I cried several times. I find the message of the movie beautiful. But... When McConaughey is >!finally reunited with his daughter, when she is an old woman and he's still in his 40's, due to relativity!<, he decides that he needs to >!fly on, and doesn't even stay with his daughter for more than 10 minutes... after missing her whole life!!< Love was absolutely central to the movie's theme up until then. Then that gave way to him self-realizing, and instead of being sad about the people in the story I became sad about Christopher Nolan's stupid writing.

Any better movies about men choosing family over self-realization? Or that choice actually Being self-realization?

title: Just found out my kid has cancer.
body:
Never thought I’d have to explain to my four year old daughter that there was something called a “tumor” inside her which was causing her tummy to hurt. She’s only four and she has a growth the size of a softball on her right kidney. Of course, I’m kicking myself for missing what now seem like obvious signs like reduced appetite and frequent stomach aches. 

Prognosis is positive. Trying to keep being the silly playful dad for her because that’s what she needs more than the worried, concerned dad.

Not sure really why I’m posting this, other than to scream into the void. Dads, hug your kids.

EDIT: I don’t have time to respond to all, but trust me, your words of support are much appreciated. Wanted to share an update. They’re fairly confident it’s Wilms, which means she has cancer on her right kidney. It’s currently a little bigger than a softball. Prognosis is good, they will operate today or tomorrow to remove and then she’ll undergo chemo to prevent reoccurrence. The surgery is super invasive, they’ll slice her abdomen open from side to side and she’ll also lose her right kidney. But, importantly, full recovery is expected.

EDIT 2: Once again, I’m humbled by the words of support and encouragement. It helps more than y’all know. My daughter’s surgery went as well as we could have hoped. The tumor did not rupture and they were able to remove it intact along with the right kidney, so she’ll officially be prone to walking in circles for the rest of her life. This was a super invasive surgery, so we’ll be in the hospital into next week. No food or drink tonight, unfortunately. They will biopsy the tumor to confirm that it’s cancerous (formality at this point) and start chemo this week. She’ll have 4-6 months of outpatient chemo. The goal is complete cure, nothing less. Cancer is awful, but we’re blessed things have turned out as they have.

title: A short story from the night shift
body:
Hello fellow dads. I'm a new dad to an 8-week old. He's cute.

My wife and I are doing shifts during my dad leave. She does mornings and I'm the night guy.

MIL made dinner tonight - scrambled eggs with potatoes and onions. A playful, but mysterious little dish. I loved it. I enjoy kimchi so I had a side of that, too.

Since the little dude arrived, my skanky witching hour delight has been Pop Tarts and milk.

On this night, I warm up my Pop Tarts and as I sit down to eat them quietly and shamefully in the dark, an insidious twisting starts in my stomach like some kind of rotten bloom. The clock starts.

I'm watching my kid while feverishly shoveling pastry into my face and contorting my body in creative ways as I tempt fate. I have shit my pants before - the threat was real, and the gods don't abide insolence. 

But I can't \*leave\* my Pop Tarts. One doesn't re-warm a Pop Tart. That's gauche.

My friends, let me tell you. I made it. I finished my Pop Tart and didn't shit my pants, though I do have a newfound appreciation for the concept of event horizon. While the diarrhea was perishing, I feel, perhaps undeservingly, that my handling of this situation bodes well for what's to come in fatherhood.

Until next time. Godspeed.

title: Colossal screw up by me and my wife (mostly me)
body:
My wife and I had to take our two boys (3y and 10mo) out yesterday, to a doctor about half an hour away. We were rushing of course, because that’s just life, and so I took my 3yo and my wife took the baby. We’ve been on very little sleep because we’re sleep training the baby. Anyway, I put the 3yo in his car seat and strapped him in. My wife has a bad back, so she usually puts the baby in his seat and I strap him in when I’m done.

While getting my toddler strapped, she verbalized to me that the baby wasn’t strapped, and I acknowledged. As I was finishing, she asked me to run back into the house to grab some socks for the baby and some water bottles for us, so I did. 

Came back out, straight into the drivers seat, handed her the water bottles, and off we went. Drove for 30 minutes, mostly on a heavily trafficked stretch of highway, and made it to the doctor just in time. Wife and both boys slept on the way. 

You know where this is going of course. My wife opens the back door and is horrified to find our baby unstrapped. To say I felt like the world’s biggest fuckup is an understatement.

We got away with it thank God. But it was a stark reminder that there are some mistakes you are just not allowed to make, or your kids could be killed. 

We both agreed that whoever places a kid in the seat has to buckle him from now on, or at least not walk away until the other person swaps with them. 

Not sure why I’m posting this story exactly. Mostly to remind myself to do a better job in the future I think.

title: Snapped last night
body:
My son is a great kid, 4, nearly 5. He is caring, shy, attentive to other kids needs. At home, he can act out,  and has major listening issues - not at school, just at home. 

Bed time is always a chore for Mom and I. He fights it tooth and nail. One more thing, one more story, oh I need to tell mom something, or whatever. Pretty normal. 

Last night he was acting up, being rough with his baby brother (4 months) and just being in general wild.  He was belly flopping on the bed. We asked him to stop. He kept going. Mom losing patience, me losing patience. We continue to politely and calmly ask him to stop. He smiled. Did it again. Pushing. 
I said if you do that one more time, no stories, no cuddles, you go to sleep alone. I asked him to repeat what I said to make sure he understood. A second later he looked at me and did it. 

Fine, sleeping alone, me and mom say goodnight and leave (left door cracked) and he lost it. Wailing, crying, screaming. Full meltdown. I came in and said that's enough, you chose this etc, I love you, good night. More ramping, and I lost it and began shouting.  I told him to shut his mouth and to lay down and not another peep. 

This worked, but mom was not happy. Did I over react by using that language? My son this morning told me it's not nice to tell people to shut their mouth, he is right, and I apologized and explained my frustration. 

Wife still angry with me. Bedtime should be happy, etc. Which I agree, but how could I have handled this different? For context, this has been an ongoing issue, I didn't just shout for no reason. Bedtime, listening and direct disobedience is a thing for sure. 

Tldr. Kid looked me in my face with a smile after days of soft parenting and disobeyed. I took no pity in his tears and applied the known consequences. Shouted at them to shut their mouth and now mom is mad.

title: I give up on bedtime.
body:
Seriously, I surrender. I’ve got two kids, ages 2 and 4, and bedtime is a never-ending nightmare. Both kids are horrible sleepers. They despise going to bed, wake up multiple times a night, and then rise at an ungodly hour. The result? We’re all cranky all day, every day.

I’m sick of hearing about the importance of establishing a “calm and consistent bedtime routine" and other such shitty advice. There is nothing calm about bedtime in our house.

We’re not stupid people, and I believe most problems have a solution, but this has us completely baffled. How is it possible to achieve a consistent result to a problem that has so many variables? It's a complex system, not a complicated one.

Every day they eat different foods, which messes with their pooping, which disrupts bedtime, which leads to a restless night, which means their energy levels are all over the place the next day, making their appetite and mood unpredictable. One day, the little one skips his nap and is overtired, resulting in a complete meltdown at bedtime. The next, they fall asleep for two minutes in the car in the afternoon and are wide awake until 11 PM. A snack before bed helps them sleep through the night one evening but gives them a sugar rush the next. Then there’s teething, random fevers, nightmares, sleep regressions, and sudden growth spurts that throw everything off.

Even if you manage some kind of routine for a few months, summer comes along and the sun is up till 10 PM. And with two kids, the difficulty isn’t just doubled, it’s multiplied. Just as one kid is ready to sleep, the other decides sleep is for the weak and wrecks the plan.

So yes, I give up on bedtime. I’m tapping out. If they refuse to go to bed, stay up then. Bother each other. I'll put my noise-cancelling headphones on and try to do my own shit as best I can. We'll live in chaos and sleep deprivation, with no end in sight. To all the parents out there still fighting the good fight, I salute you. May your battles be shorter and your victories sweeter.

title: Wife and I bump heads on eating dinner together at the table
body:

We currently do separate dinners just because its easier for our routine (although I'm getting a little sick of making 2 dinners) and we always spend a good 2 hours with them after work and picking them up from daycare. I find it hard to push this because she doesn't see it as a priority and I feel guilty pushing a routine that will make our current routine a little harder/different.

My fear is as they get older, they wont want to spend as much time with us (and be busy with their own stuff) and starting the tradition now will at least allow us to have that time together with no distractions. 

Have any of you clashed over this? Anyone with older kids find my wife's thoughts to be correct and find different ways to guarantee the valuable time with their kids?

title: Had the worst dream of my entire life and it seemed so real. I couldn't get halfway through telling my wife before she said she couldn't listen anymore. I have to share with somebody.
body: I had the worst dream of my entire life last Saturday night. It was one of those dreams that just seemed so real and has stuck with me over the last few days. So there I was in my dream at a family barbecue at an unknown location but with all my friends and family. I realize I don't see my two year old daughter Emily and look up to my wife and see she's not with her either. No big deal I though she's with grandmom, grand pop, an aunt or uncle or cousin as I have a big family. I start combing the backyard saying her name to no avail. The saying turns to screaming as my wife and family join in. In that instant I knew something was terribly wrong. I look over at the in ground pool full of people swimming and run over as fast as I can. There she is motionless on the bottom with her green pants and pink long sleeve shirt. I dive in and swim to the bottom and grab her but she isn't moving. I swim to the surface and as I break the water line with her in my hands I wake up heart racing in a cold sweat. It was a dream but I went through the worst emotions imaginable and I'm still not right. I hold her extra tight and have been sleeping in her bed. I don't know what I would do it I lost her and it that very real moment it appeared I had. I tried to share with my wife but only got halfway through before she said she couldn't listen anymore. I had to share with someone. Thanks for reading.

title: My 5 month old daughter fell out of her stroller down the driveway tonight
body:
Daddit,
A little over an hour ago, I messed up bad and my 5mo took a spill down my steep driveway. There’s no way I can really do this story any justice, but here’s how it went: 

My wife got out for a trip to the gym, a rare occasion. She’s probably been away from our daughter for an hour+ less than 12 times since she was born. So I’m in charge, and when I’m on duty, as I’m sure you all do too, I’ll do whatever it takes to keep my daughter occupied, e.g., sing in the mirror, dance on countertops (her on the counter, not me), beatbox, whatever it takes really. Well she starts to get restless so we quickly go outside to the garage, I put her in her car seat that’s already in the stroller. Quickly run back in, grab my dog, slip on flip flops and return back to her in the stroller. I have a podcast blaring out of my pocket. 

Well, we start on our way, making faces at each other as we start to go down the steep hill of my driveway. It all happened so quick but I remember this in slow motion - her car seat rolled backwards out of the stroller down our steep driveway. She wasn’t buckled in. 

I let everything go and run over to scoop her up. A car is coming down the road, the stroller is rolling into the street, the innards of the car seat are scattered across the steep driveway and my untrained dog’s leash is no longer in my hand. My 5mo old daughter, the true light of my world, screaming a new sound I’ve never heard before in my arms. I run over and grab the leash and book it inside. Pacing back and forth with my baby girl crying. Fuck the stroller and the car seat out there. The only thing I can think about is whether or not I just ruined her life, if she’s going to be okay, the extent of the damage, the god damn steep driveway, my carelessness for not buckling the car seat in. Tears are in my eyes and my daughter’s tears on my chest. 

Just a mere two minutes of crying go by and she sobs herself back to calm and content, cuddled close on my chest. Massive sigh of relief there. I take her to the bathroom mirror. Still cuddled on my chest, she smiles and makes a sound. Now my wet eyes are tears of joy. 

Fast forward to now- she has a small red mark/mini egg on her forehead and a light scrape on her knee. She’s acting normal, smiley and fun, and now tucked into bed. 

Although incredibly grateful to God or whatever higher power was protecting her, I still feel like I let down my baby. It’s my duty to protect her. 5 months old. She can’t even crawl. What kinda guy doesn’t even check to see if the car seat is buckled into a stroller before pushing their child. I need to be better and I will be better. 

So this is my PSA: Guys, buckle your kids into the stroller. Or at the very least, buckle the car seat into the stroller.

Edit: Thanks everyone for your stories and advice. It helps a lot hearing others have also been through similar experiences, you all best yourself up but your kids are all okay. 

To those asking about my wife’s reaction - I called her a few minutes after things settled down to let her know what happened and that I’m monitoring her behavior. My wife is an RN and handled this really well. Basically just assessed the severity of the situation- no blame or anything like that. When she finished up and came home from the gym, she looked at our daughter, saw everything appears to be fine (aside from the two exterior scuffs), and carried on momming. Very supportive and loving along the way.

EDIT 2: It’s morning, nearly 15 hours after the accident. She doesn’t have the red mark on her head anymore. Just has a slightly scraped knee. Acting her usual self. I got the accident on video off my ring cam. It’s a miracle she didn’t hit her head. My family is blessed. Thank you all for the advice, stories and well wishes. This will be ingrained in my memory for a long time to come.

body:
Cis woman here. I don't have any children, yet.

My own biological father was near absent in my life. I met my real (step)Dad as a teenager. He died last year, my parents were together for only 14 years... Cancer took him away at 51.

My biological father is a narcissist that I cut contact with at 16. Given my experiences, I've always been more observant of men with children.
I read a comment on here once, many years ago that stuck with me. It was an old guy that said "This is the best generation of Dads"...

I can't help but agree.

I see Dads with their kids all the time now.
Seeing posts on here that show your love for your children, expressing the same emotions and sentiment from the female version is beautiful.

There was once a time that I truly believed that men cannot love, they're only with women for the sex and they stay for the sex. I stopped believing that when I was 16...

I hope to find a man who can be a good parent, who won't abandon or abuse his children. An active parent. I think I'll find it easy enough.
Thank you for the hope, the love and the smiles.

I know it's hard to be a good parent when your employer continues the old ways, expecting you to work as though you don't have kids to pick up or housework to do.

Just know you are making a difference. We are watching. We are proud.
Thank you.

title: AITA for scolding my wife for feeding ‘supplement’ to wrong child
body:
Came home and found out my wife fed the doctor-prescribed electrolytes and probiotics to my younger one, as well as the older one. I had already clarified in messages to the family specific instructions to feed the older child. 

Taken aback because I only took the older child to the doc today and it was fairly obvious from how I updated in the group chat.

So anyway I raised my voice and asked her why she did that, and she said she had so much going on and too tired and she thought that it was good-to-have type meds so she also gave the younger one since she also had vomit symptoms.

I said it was incredulous that anyone would do that as this was medication and being tired is not a good reason to just give meds flippantly whether it is supplementary or essential. If she can do this now what if in future there are more heavy meds that require diligent follow up. I am upset because she got defensive and didn’t even apologise.

I am angry because it just feels irresponsible to me but I don’t know how to close this case. All I want is for her to recognise her mistake and not repeat it again.

It really sucks that we have to make sure our children are prepared and trained for it.

title: Bro dads - I just need to vent about my ex-wife (my son's mom).
body:
From the time we divorced 12 years ago, my son has been with me about 75% of the time, though in our divorce agreement it was 50-50.  At the time, I was barely employed and she was asked to pay child support because of the disproportion in our income. 

About a year later, my  employment situation improved and we discontinued the child support.  

About 7 years ago, my ex-wife had one tumultuous relationship after another and my son start to stay with me about 90% of the time with very little to no financial support from her.  

Later on since we have had several discussions about finances, she decided that she was going to buy my son his first car, and then a new one when he graduates High School.

She stalled several times and more than twice told me "I have a friend selling an awesome car, perfect for our son.  I will get a good deal." and then nothing will happen.

She decided we will just find a car for my son, but her budget of $2000 was unrealistic for a dependable car.  Finally, with all her excuses and drama, I decided, F*CK IT!!!  I will buy him a car.

We got him a nice Mitsubishi Eclipse that was owned by a mechanic, so the car was very well taken care off and clean.  The only thing was, it was a stick (manual transmission), but my son was excited about having a stick shift since he has seen videos of people trying to steal cars only to fail because they did not know how to drive a stick.

We brought home the Eclipse and my son, my brother and I started to make the car more his own.  We bought and installed a new stereo head unit with bluetooth to replace the OEM one.  Installed a back-up camera.  Replaced a few small parts and basically he started to learn and care for his car.

My ex-wife refuses to get in his car, because it's a stick and she can't drive it. And because of it she hates it, regardless of how my son and I feel about the car.

Yesterday she called me with another "my friend is selling her car and it's perfect for our son" speech.  I mentioned the obvious that he already has a car and she mentions again that she hates it. 

She has not contributed one dime to anything that has to do with the car including maintenance, insurance, financing, etc.  I told her that our son loves the car but she does not care, she hates it.

It's just frustrating.  Thanks for listening (reading), bro dads.  

RANT OVER.

title: You’re all doing great, and I’m proud of you.
body:
I don’t know if this is the right place to post this, but I hope this isn’t too intrusive. While I have a fantastic mother who busts her tail to this day to give me a good life, and who id give the world to, I’ve never met my father. I spoke to him once over the phone on my sixth birthday, and he wrote me one birthday card. I’ve had no contact for the rest of my 21 years. The last school picture my mom sent him was 7th grade, because we never got any response. He may not even recognise me if he saw me on the street.

My birthday is coming up soon, and that always seems to bring up this tight knot in my stomach. I’ve suffered from really bad abandonment fears since I finally accepted he didn’t want to be in my life. I never got to go to the father daughter dances or have a male role model in my life, never got to play video games with him or play on his drum kit or cook with him. I used to be petulant about it, telling myself I never needed a dad. Now, I still understand that I can be strong, but I know there’s an experience in life I’ll always miss.

You’re all doing such great jobs — fatherhood is no easy task, parenting in general is a journey I know I couldn’t go on. But you’re in your child’s lives, some of you fighting to do so. You’re so integral to them. It’s sounds weird to say, but I really am proud of you. There’s a lot of bad parents. Men and women who abandon their children, who are distant, who don’t have the love in them for their children. Please keep on doing amazing things for them. 

Thank you,

Cassini.

title: My Scary Story
body:
So my daughter is 6 weeks old.  Last week we went to our pediatricians appointment.  I met my wife and daughter there since I was at work.  After the doc got done with my daughter she was fussy so I decided to go hang out in the car with her (she likes the engine noise and the radio) while my wife asked some questions and made the next appointment.
I had my daughter in the back seat in her car seat and I was up front kinda hanging out.  By this time the car trick had worked and she was snoozing.  The tingly bit in the back of my head started up and I noticed someone staring into the back window at my daughter.  I rolled down the window and asked what he needed.  I was on guard but polite.  He asked if he could hold my daughter.  I said "no, she's asleep".  Besides, I wasn't letting a stranger hold my daughter.  He asked again, only this time he wasn't really asking.  I again refused, and made sure the tone of my voice expressed some finality.  This is when he reached for the door handle.  
Now I don't remember opening my door, but I do remember making the decision to draw my gun.  I'm a concealed carry holder and always carry when I'm working (I have a risky job).  My order was clear, "Step away".  Now I doubt it was the tone of my voice that made him run off but he did.  I holstered my weapon and called the police.  The hospital is right around the corner from my peds office and they must have been there because I had two cruisers with me within a minute.  Within 5 there were two more.  My wife had a near come apart when she walked out of the office and there were four police cars around us.  
I explained what had happened.  I was very up front with the officers that I had a concealed weapon and that I had drawn it.  They inspected it, ran my license, etc but ultimately it wasn't an issue.  
The guy was found later that day.  He was on probation for sexual assault to a minor and was on the Megan's Law registry, which he had violated.
Moral of the story:  I will never be in public with my daughter and not prepared to defend us.  Ever.

title: Tell your wife when it's hard
body:
TLDR; Communicate when things are difficult, even if you make it seem easy. 

Sometimes it feels like being a dad is a thankless position. I thought being a super-dad meant taking as much of the stress off my partner as possible to make her life easy and give the kids the best childhood. What it also did was build resentment towards myself because I would take on larger and larger responsibilities within the family and home and I would catch my wife scrolling on her phone while I "did everything". 

It was my fault. Really. I kept saying yes and smiled. Because I work hybrid- I do the morning drop off, afternoon pickup, carry a full time job, and clean the house and have dinner ready most days. As my wife works nearby, she'll sometimes come home for lunch so I'll have that ready for her. When the workday is over, I'll do the cleaning up,  playtime and homework with the kids, bathtime, and bed routine. The yardwork is mine, the financials are mine, and the midweek errands are mine. During the weekend I plan the dates, schedule the activities, and ensure it all runs so smoothly that things just flow right. I'm not saying all this to show how much I do, but rather because I suspect many of us are in the same position and haven't realized how much work we do 

You may be asking yourself "well dang, what does the wife do?", and that's the point. I took on as much as I could with a smile and a cheer and I do everything possible to make it seem like it's no bother at all to add one more task. I actively discouraged her from doing chores saying "go relax- I got this." or "of course you can brunch with your girlfriends- the kids and I will stay here!" The downside is that I did it so well that my wife had no idea of the scope. M 

I was asked to travel for work recently, a week+
event, and when I left she was sure she could handle it all- when I came back, the day before Fathers Day, she announced before friends, family, and God that she didn't realize how much I did and how easy I made it look. I didn't want to go with "I told you so", because I didn't, but it made me realize that I need to share the mental load, if nothing else. 

I'm not complaining or comparing myself to single parents, but it is hard. We dads may seem to have these huge shoulders to carry the burden of a family, and we do, but there's no reason why we can't let our partner be aware of the toll it takes.  We can't assume our partner will "just know" because we often  hide it well enough. You don't have to give up being a super dad, but let your partner  know that you need a break because you did this and that and the other thing- they probably didn't realize it. If you handle everything, talk to your partner about sharing the load- the point is to NOT fill yourself to capacity and communicate. 

And then tell her when it's hard...I think we both know what I mean there.

title: Daughter's first birthday party cancelled
body:
My first born just turned 6 today.  Prior to this year, all celebrations for her birthday had been with family.  She was really excited to be able to invite friends from school and the neighborhood to celebrate with her.  We spent the last week buying all of the decor, party favors, food, and drinks.  We were doing a Frozen themed party, and had hired a party planner to come dressed as Elsa.

I already realized a couple weeks ago when a couple kids were not able to come that we should plan her party early in the future to avoid cold season and Thanksgiving.  We still had enough kids to still allow my daughter to enjoy her special day.

This morning sucked.  We heard back from three of the moms that their kids would not be able to come.  Only one gave an explanation, and it was for health reasons.  That would have left only one friend able to still come, my daughter's best friend.

My wife was able to act quickly and find a fun activity for the family today, and my daughter was happy about that.  That means that she would not be able to see her friend, though, as they had plans for later in the day.  That is when my brave little girl finally broke down and started crying.

She seems calm now, but my wife and I cannot help but think that we failed somehow.  I know we can plan better in the future, and we have learned some things, but it will always hurt having to disappoint my daughter.

title: I want everyone’s best stories about pregnancy brain and food aversions / cravings
body:
We always laugh about it years after but in the moment all the the forgetfulness, nausea, aversions and wild craving can be a lot. This time around it’s hitting especially hard and early, and we just started meds that ramp it up to 11.

We both can really use a few laughs while we deal with the roller coaster of hormones and emotions. Currently my wife does not want to eat anything except for Tostitos, which are apparently crack.

Our best story from last time: A few years ago we did blood work in the morning (and had apple juice) then went to Lowe’s to pick out paint colors for the nursery. She got so nauseous she had to lay down right there in the paint aisle. Someone came over to ask if she was ok. She said she might throw up. The guy ran to get her a bucket. As he was running back toward her, she threw up the apple juice and breakfast all over the floor.. right by his feet.

He just looked so disappointed looking down at the mess, then shrugged and flipped the bucket upside down to cover the mess. I heard them announce on the loudspeaker “cleanup in paint department.” It was like something out of a cartoon.

By then there was a crowd around us. People asking if she has some medical condition and should we call an ambulance. This isn’t normal and looks so bad, they said. Then I told everyone she was pregnant. There was just a collective “OHH” from the crowd. Oh ok, then she’s fine, someone said. And the crowd dispersed. The Lowe’s employees were so nice about it and helped us check out and stayed with her while I brought the car around. We went home and she went straight to bed and slept for 4 hours.

To this day, she has never returned to that store, and has never had apple juice again 🤣

Still we wouldn’t change this wonderful and exciting time for anything. Let’s hear your stories!

title: Clever Girl
body:
**Setup:** 

I have twins, a boy and a girl, both just turned 3. They share a room.

My daughter is autistic, and has trouble communicating. She doesn't really talk (just a few words), and doesn't tell us when she's hungry or tired or even hurt. We just have to guess.

When my son wakes up in the morning, he bangs on the door or yells until one of us comes to get him. But if my daughter wakes up first, she just sits in her bed quietly, sadly until we come in for some other reason.

But where people often screw up is by mistaking "inability to communicate" with "unintelligent".

**Story:**

So the day after their birthday, all the new toys are still out in the living room. She wakes up first the next day, and decides she wants to go play with them. But how? The door is closed, and she doesn't know how to wake us up. A conundrum, to be sure. The only birthday toy in their room is the foam, Nerf-like Thor's hammer.

So I am awoken to the sound of my son screaming in pain. I run in to the room. He's half-asleep, clutching his head, yelling "Ouch! Ouch!". She is standing next to his bed, Thor's hammer in hand. As soon as I open the door, she gets the biggest grin on her face, runs out the door, and goes straight to her new toys in the living room.

She was hitting him with the hammer in his sleep until he woke up screaming. Because he knows how to get our attention, *she used his pain as an alarm to get the door open.*

I'm impressed with the problem-solving, but terrified at the implications.

title: First Father's Day since wife's hysterectomy - we never had kids.
body:
Throw Away Account

I am 36, and my wife 35. We have been married for 15 years, and while we always talked about having kids, we never did. Both of us wanted children, the time was just never right for us. But we both looked forward to one day being parents, and growing our family. About two years ago my wife began having pain in her hip, which kept her awake most nights, and made managing through the day difficult.  After a visit to the doctor and a few tests we learned of numerous fibroids on the inside and outside of her uterus. The first course of care was a prescription of birth control pills, the hope was that they would shrink the fibroids, thereby reducing the pain; unfortunately this did not work.

We met with her doctor about next steps, and her options were not great. The first option was to burn them off, which did not guarantee they would not return. The second option was to tie them off, keeping the blood from getting to the fibroids and they would die off, again no guarantee that they would not come back, in fact the doctor was certain of their return. The final option which was the most drastic was a full hysterectomy, the only guarantee that the fibroids would be gone forever.  The decision needed to be made, we were both scared, and all I wanted was for pain to go away and her suffering to stop. We knew this would be the final word on our having a baby, but that was nothing more than collateral damage at this point.

She had the surgery, stayed in the hospital for two days, and took about a month to recover, but there has been no more pain, and her spirits haven’t been so high in I couldn’t remember how long.
But today has been a rough one for me. We had brunch at her parents with her sister, her husband, and their new baby. As my father-in-law and brother-in-law opened their cards and gifts, I couldn’t help but feel a bit sad. Yes we have been married for 15 years, but the decision to not have children was always our own. Now that decision has been made for us, and it never really hit me until today. There is no way I can talk about this with my wife, I know she already feels responsible for us not being able to have a baby, I have no desire to add to her plate. I don’t even know if I have a right to have these feelings, but I do, and putting them down has made me feel just a bit better. But I will be happy when today is over.

I know we can adopt, and while that is a noble action, it is not the same as having our own. We haven’t dismissed the idea completely, but I don’t think it is something which would work for us.

I do want to wish all of the dads a happy father's day. Please do not ever take your children for granted.

TL;DR – Wife had uterus removed, I will never get a tacky tie for Father’s Day

title: Scary dad day and dealing with severe anxiety.
body:
So let me own this and start by saying I suffer from depression and anxiety. It's not something I disclose to potential employers, but I do own it. Since becoming a dad I have much better control over this. 
I had to rush my 4yo daughter to urgent care last weekend as she had severe hip pain and couldn't really walk. Her tears started to become my tears. I kept composure as the doctor ran my daughter through tests and discussed her recent medical history. I was thinking the worst. She quickly was diagnosed with Toxic synovitis. They say it's incredibly common yet no one I know has heard of it. It's when a cold virus reappears and causes hip swelling weeks after recovery. 
After the diagnosis of relatively good news I just let it out. The doctor had to tell me it was ok there was nothing I could do as a father to prevent this. Even my daughter just gave me a hug while I was crying a bit at the doctor's office.
She got her day on the couch along with ice cream, screen time, a 2hr puppet show and got to be carried for a day. 
The next day my wife had to work so it was just me with our baby and my 4yo. She just kept jumping around. All day. Doing yoga behind my back. Just one day of rest and ibuprofen is all she needed.
My anxiety hit me really hard. It's gotten so much better and my panic attack frequency is soo much lower since being a dad. But when panic attacks do come they seem to hit harder and longer. Parenting does funny things.
Just wanted to share a story with you all.

title: Guys, I dropped the ball
body:
This was today. 

Well, a few weeks Ago, the worst culminating today. 

My wife hates hospitals and wants nothing more from this world than to deliver a baby in a birthing center, with no medications, no fear of c sections, with a midwife. 

I'm a nurse. I was hesitant at first, but got fully on board, and became extremely excited. We've been going to classes with the birthing center. Meeting other families. Relaxing in the spa-like rooms where she'll be delivering, with no medical interference. 

Quiet, filled with music, her and I, the dream she's always had.

Well, the insurance company said they were out of network. But no worries! A facility upgrade rider would make it all ok, and I just needed to apply before the birth. Phew! 

Here I am. Twenty days away from our due date. To be told it isn't covered. At all. Under any circumstances. 

A charge that was anticipated to be $500 is now $5,000+ and out of my budget, easily. 

My wife is devastated. I'm a healthy mixture of angry and disappointed that my wife can't have what she wants out of such a special event. She has been beyond looking forward to this. 

So now we have to find a hospital. With strangers we've never met. To give birth in a clinical environment neither of us want in any way whatsoever. 

Fuck. Me.

title: It is hard to come back to empty house after I drive my daughter back to her mom’s
body:
My daughter is almost 4 and lives with her mom. I spend quite a lot of time with my daughter. Well more than my official time share per divorce ruling. I am much more than a typical divorced weekend dad, I love it and have a good hang of the whole thing, including girly stuff, rainbows and unicorns. 

I live well, my daughter has her own bedroom at my place, her own space and stuff. She has friends here, we got our own habits and routines, we go to „our” shop for a snack, and so on. Even though a 3,5-4 year old is a handful, time when she is around is a joy. There’s energy, there’s fun, doing stuff together. Good time. 

But the time I drive her back to her mom’s or drop her off to kindergarten, and I know I will not see her for some time, fucking sucks. Usually it is just a couple of days, sure. But I truly fucking hate going back to my place in that moment, it just feels so empty. Like, an hour ago she was blabbing what shoes to wear and what teddy bear to take for a ride, and now it is just empty, with snacks on the floor and other traces of little girl activity. 


It is just too empty and too quiet. Even though I think I’m mature emotionally and quite stable in that regard, it just feels like it is too hard to adjust, like the change is almost too radical for the brain to adjust.

It gets better, sure. But the first day fucking sucks. 

Not asking for advice or anything. Just venting in the blind I guess.

title: They don’t grow too fast
body:
People keep saying that “kids grow too fast” and I think that’s complete bollocks. Don’t misunderstand me, I’m very fond of the awesome moments we had and I’m still sad sometimes that I can’t rock my baby to sleep (unless she’s down with a cold that is) but my daughter is making me happy every day and I look forward to see her smile tomorrow.

I used to be focused on the past and dwell on mistakes, missed opportunities and such but since her birth, I’m better able to enjoy the present and I’m looking forward to the future.

I’m writing this while thinking about a good friend who died recently (went to her funeral this afternoon) and yes I miss her and there’s a lot of things I wish I had told her but I’m not crushed as I know I would have been three years ago before my daughter was born. My friend lived in the present and she was happy. I guess I managed to understand how she viewed the world after all.

Hug your kids, not because you might not see them tomorrow but because being with them today makes you happy. They don’t grow too fast, they grow at just the right speed - accelerate to keep up.

title: Advice on how to come back from this….
body:
Hey guys,

So while not 100% dad related, I had a moment last night that I’m sad to say may change my marriage forever…

My wife was on a work trip last week, which left me alone with the kids for the week.  It happens a few times a year but for some reason, this time, both of us felt the separation much more than normal.  I’m not sure if it is because of the holidays coming up or because of a few other things we have going on.  But we both agreed that this trip felt much longer than the average one.  

So, anyway, my wife comes home last night, takes her normal post-plane shower, hangs out with the kids until bedtime and heads off to bed to relax while I put the kids to bed.  

Finally, I join her in bed, nothing dirty or anything going on but she lays on my chest so she could cuddle in.  After a minute, she says, “I hope I’m not smothering you, I just wanted to be close to you!” 

….and this is where my life changed forever…

In my attempt to convey to her that I missed her as much as wanted to be close to her as well, I said to her, without thinking, “Are you kidding? I want you inside of me….”

Now…what I meant was I wish she was so close to me that our bodies somehow merged into one so we physically couldn’t be any closer…..but that’s not what I said, unfortunately….I said, to my wife who is, let’s just say, not afraid to break my balls, “I want you inside of me….” 

How do I come back from this?

title: Helps for a depressed new dad?
body:
My husband and I had a baby 4 months ago. My husband has always had anxiety and depression that was managed with medication but it seems to be getting worse since the baby arrived. 

I don't even know where to start. He's always miserable, overly stressed, working too much, and suffering from poor sleep. He loves his baby but He's unhappy with himself, his job is too stressful because no one works as hard as him and he 'has to do it all'. There's never a day where I ask how he is and he has something positive to say. 

I ask him often what I can do to help, I try to make sure he gets a huge block for exercise on the weekend (it's not frequent enough), he said hearing my problems stresses him out so I try not to bring things up if I can. I'm really not a particularly emotional person but I do ocassionally go throughshort rough patches like anyone else. Anytime I'm struggling with something he mentions he can't deal; it's too stressful for him. 

I've suggested therapy 3 times a week at this point but he didn't find it helpful in the past and doesn't want to try it again. When he went through this 15 years ago he was always angry at me and constantly started fights with lots of yelling and criticizing. At the time I tried everything to help him out- took him to hypnotherapy, yoga, etc. the medication is the only thing that worked. Luckily that is behind us and we were happy for many many years. 

I know you're not supposed to say this but he's making me miserable and I'm annoyed he won't help himself or just get over it. Just do something about it. Now we have a baby I don't have the time to try to help him find solutions. He needs to help himself.  

I don't know what else I should add or what I should do. I guess I just wanted to get it out there and maybe that will help me think through what comes next. I just wish he was more resilient.

title: *Venting / question* As a very tech-y dad, how do you talk your significant other *out* of needless technology purchases, i.e. a touchscreen toaster?

We found out that we are having a girl, being like (I assume most guys) I wanted to have a little boy to bro it up with, I stupidly built up the picture of being a dad revolving around having a boy (and I made a post a little while ago second guessing my Dad-idness, which I'm still doing) and now that we are having a girl it's thrown everything for a loop for me. 

I have a nephew and a few neices, and I connect with the nephew more.. I get along with the girls fine, but there is always a small bit of awkwardness, I don't know what it is, I can girly it up with the best of them, I'm not ashamed to wear a dress or skirt, or paint my nails, or braid hair.. But there is just something there that I don't seem to have with my nephew.

I'm a 'bloke-y' guy, I work on cars, ride motorbikes, weld, build shit, camp, 4wd.. I was looking forward to teaching my son all these kinds of things. 
I know 'nurture' has alot to do with it but I can't see myself really doing these types of things with a daughter, 'most girls (yeah yeah I know...) aren't into this type of fun, and would rather play house and dolls. I'm worried that there will be a bit of a disconnect there between me and her. 

Anyway, getting to the point.. To the dad's out there that have been in the same situation, how was/is it? Did all these thoughts up and disappear once bub was born? Did it take time to adjust to having a daughter instead of a son? 

To the dad's that wanted a girl from the start and got one, I'd like to hear the reasons why you wanted a girl, maybe I'm overlooking things or something..

title: Push present for dad?

I never wanted to push him, I had /have so much love and respect for him and my bonus kids. I'd be lying though if I said it didn't hurt. We were devastated. I've never seen my husband so hurt. We lost another and he completely shut down. It was a dark time for both of us. We fought a lot and somehow it didn't destroy our marriage.

We continued trying for another 2 years, for three total. We had started seeing a fertility specialist when we managed to get pregnant on our own again. Third time was a charm and I got to bring home the baby boy I prayed so hard for yesterday. Not only did my husband give me the baby I desperately desired, he was literally perfect for the entire labor. Since we've been home, he has jumped up to retrieve our son every time he cries and I haven't had to lift a finger. (I tore pretty bad and we opted for a birthing center so we were home 4 hours after he was born)

This man literally deserves the world, but I can't give it to him. Please give me some ideas.

title: LO had emergency surgery
body:
Hey pops and lurking moms!

I had the day off this Thursday to have a scheduled 2,5 year checkup with our little guy. While preparing breakfast which is his favorite meal hands down, gladly eats once at home and then again at daycare, he starts to complain about tummy aches.

Since he was born with a condition (duodenal atresia) that required surgery when he was just a few days old we’ve been told to have a low bar with seeking medical attention for him with tummy related things. 

Aches continued and he refused food and just wanted to lean against me so I packed a quick bag and headed to the hospital. Got admitted and he basically slept all day, just woke up to cry from pain and throw up once. Slept through X-rays and them drawing blood. Overnight it got worse, lots of throwing up, slight fever, pain and abdominal swelling. So in the morning we got transferred to the same hospital where he was born and had his first surgery in, new X-rays which show some intestinal obstruction but unclear what, but surgery was needed to find out more and correct.

So quickly transferred internally to surgery, showered and prepped and I got to hold him in my arms while they prepared the anesthesia. Then had to leave for a 4-5 hours which felt like forever while they operated on him. 

Surgery was a success and now my wife and I is staying with him for his recovery, probably a week at this hospital, which is in a different city than we live in, then probably a few days at primary hospital and a few days at home, all depending on how it goes.

He’s been sleeping most of his recovery so far but wakes up wanting to eat or drink which he can’t do yet, and it’s so heartbreaking to have to deny him this, but a few more days and it should be okay.

I don’t really know what I hope to gain from this post, but mentally I think it’s good to type out and share, knowing all the support I’ve seen all you guys dish out while I’ve been lurking it seemed like the right place.

It’s just tough knowing my son is barely 2 1/2 years old and already had 2 surgeries, more than most people have all their life.

title: Is there something I'm missing in this situation?

I actually think it is because she knows that she can basically say "I'm having a rest this weekend" and that's that unless i have pre booked something in advance.  

I think it would be a good time to list out the daily routine now, so days I’m working from home look like this.

6am – I get up with the baby, do breakfast etc…. mum comes down after having a shower usually gone 7, I then go and shower come back down to grab my coffee and am then asked to put the baby down for a nap around 8am and start work, 

9am – Baby wakes up, Mum dresses her, takes her out for a walk, to the shop, swimming etc…….

11am - I take my laptop downstairs, prepare lunch for when Mum and baby return, 

11:30am - I take the dog out for a walk 

12:30pm – mum puts baby down for a nap 

3:30pm -baby wakes up, mum goes downstairs with baby, I take my laptop downstairs and prepare dinner whilst finishing up work for the day. 

4:15pm I finish work and we eat dinner 

5pm – I bath baby, mum washes pots 

6:45 – we both put baby to bed after I do the majority of the playing upto that point

Mum does most of the clothes washing and does hoover the downstairs during that first nap. That 3 hours during the main nap however is totally free. I get that that she can’t really disappear for 3 hours but there are plenty of things she could do for herself within that time, she chooses to sit in bed glued to her phone. I would kill for that free time during the day.

The day I go into the office, her mum comes round does a clean through of the house takes both the baby and dog out and baths the baby before I get back from the office (about half 5), I still do the wake up duties (I just set my alarm earlier to shower before baby gets up)

When I take over at the weekend I don’t get any of the help which I give her. I Take both the baby and the dog out at the same time, I have to make the lunch when I get back and then I make the evening meal during that 3 hour nap. The only time I feel I truly get to myself is after 9pm when everyone else goes to bed and Tuesday night where I play football for an hour (after baby has gone to bed) 

I mange to get about one day (well 5 hours as I still do wake up, back before 3pm and kick something off in the slow cooker before I go) a month in which I can golf with my friends, but the mood I have to deal with the following days after asking permission sours the experience, she usually gets her mum round on these days too… 

My Gf treats my work days as days off and when I suggested my alternate weekend idea she said I already get enough time off. Is this a valid view point that I’m just not seeing or can anyone suggest anything  different that I could propose to her?

title: Nightmare potty training

title: You can have it both ways if you're wrong both ways.
body:
My wife works a weekend shift. It's not ideal that we have so few days off together, but it's the balance we strike right now. I work 4 10hr days during the week, and we have 1 day off together each week. Near the beginning of each week sometime around Monday or Tuesday evening, I'll be told that she was disappointed at the state of the house after my weekend of non-stop dad-and-toddler time. Frequently the word "disaster" is used to describe things. I try to get as much done as I can in that nap window, but it does vary. This means the nap window can be filled with chores, and maybe a minute to myself for lunch... but I routinely hear from her a day or two later that what got done was insufficient. 

Yesterday, my daughter was playing nicely in her play area, and I was cleaning in the kitchen. I can see her from the kitchen, but I guess while my back was turned she darted over to the desk and started scribbling with an inkpen. she scribble on my wife's planner (over last week and this weekend pages), and on a notepad. Miraculously, I caught her before any real damage was done. All ink had gone on paper, and nothing of real value. 

My wife saw it, and got really upset though. I told her what happened, and that I'd caught it before anything worse happened, and put the pen out of reach. She declares now that I wasn't paying enough attention. That if "she had time to do this then she could have done worse things or hurt herself". It just feels like I can't win here... and not only that it feels like the problem isn't that I'm swinging too far one way. I'm somehow managing to double fail. 

I tried to communicate this, but now I'm "too defensive". Just feeling a bit beaten down here. My wife frequently lets me know she gets more done than I do, but she also has 3 days a week when our daughter is at pre-school. I hate feeling like what we do for the household are always being weighed out to determine who contributes more, and I'm always the one coming up short.

title: My mother in law spanked my daughter (3Y10M)--my wife and I are resolutely against physical punishment.
body:
TLDR; my daughter had a tantrum while I was at work and my MIL lost control and spanked her even though my wife and I are resolutely anti-corporal punishment. 

Lately my little girl, I’ll call her E (3Y10M), has become a full-fledged 'threenager.' I posted a while back about my wife worrying about her having a mental condition, but she’s just a willful and stubborn soon-to-be four year old. We’ve adapted to her tantrums and we’ve been figuring out how to redirect her or letting her cool off depending on the degree of tantrum. We’ve been making headway, but grandma is not along for the ride. 

My MIL--who has lived with us since we all got shut in together during COVID--has been getting more and more aggressive with E as she goes through this new phase. My MIL's limited patience has given way to shouting, calling E names and even openly swearing in front of her. My wife has tried her best to get her mom to cut the bullshit, and to get her to take some time away from the house. Frankly, the only reason I haven’t kicked her to the curb myself is because my wife insists that she needs her mom’s help around the house. 

Well, last night I was on duty to watch study hall until 10:00 PM (very normal for teachers at boarding schools in our country). My wife messages me that E has been being a pain in the ass that night. Later she tells me that E had a bath but is going into tantrum mode, doesn’t want to put on her pants or underwear and is rolling around on the hard wood floors saying she doesn’t want to be clean. That is clearly an awful situation and I wish I were at home to deal with it. Before I can even type a response message, my wife tells me that my mother in law--who has been told countless times that we are vehemently against physical punishment--bent E over and spanked her. Afterward my wife took E into the bedroom and locked the door. 

I won’t go into a play by play of how our conversation went or how her conversation with her mom went. I want to throw this horrible woman out on her ass, but my wife has asked me to let her deal with it. My MIL says that she is beside herself with regret and admits that she lost control and says it will never happen again. My wife and MIL took her out of preschool so that grandma can ‘make it up to E’ today by taking her to the play place and buying her some toys. 

Here’s the deal though; she lost control. The very fact that she used that language shows me that if she is allowed to watch my daughter any more then there will always be a risk of this happening again. Also the ‘making it up to E’ strikes me as the kind of behavior a domestic abuser would display--you know, apologizing and suddenly behaving like a saint after clocking their partner. I am almost certain that if she stays in the house then this will happen again, but my wife says I need to have more faith in her and her family. 

So here’s my rock and a hard place: I want this woman out of my house immediately for the safety and welfare of my daughter, but my wife has specifically asked me to let her handle it. She is handling it by giving her mom a second chance, which sees me worried that my daughter will experience more of this kind of what I would frankly call abuse and my wife and I will see more casual disregard for our parenting ethics.

How do I navigate this? Has anyone had any similar experience?

title: Today was rough
body:
Today my youngest had her preschool graduation, which are always cute and I enjoy. But it was hard to be there too. 

One of her classmates died a few months ago, very unexpectedly. This would have been bad enough but I was also the medic that responded to the call. 

We thought this kid was going to be fine, we got pulses back on scene, he was trying to breath on his own, and at the ER he was responding a little bit. 

The next day he died. 

It was a gut punch certainly. We thought he was going to be okay, but he wasn’t. 

Not my first peds death, and I’ve even had some since then, but the fact he was in my daughter’s class definitely made him stick with me. None of them are easy though. 

His parents were there today and they did a little moment for him during the celebration. Hard enough to be reminded of it, but it’s my job and while these things hurt I cannot even imagine how his parents are. I’m not sure I could have been there today if I was in their position. 

Afterward, his mom came up to me and gave me a hug and said “thank you for giving us a chance to say goodbye.”

I was really hoping she didn’t even know who I was but she did remember me. I lost it after this moment and had to go out away from everyone. Thankfully my wife and a coworker of mine were there and they understood and helped me get my shit together. 

Sorry for the rant, Dads. I just had to put this down and share it with someone. I’ve been a wreck all day since then. Thanks for reading my problems I guess.


EDIT: Thank you to everyone. These comments have honestly helped a lot. Love you all.

I feel despair and depressed. I can't help but feel pretty down every time when I see him being so happy with my wife. title: My daughter (4) has been touched inappropriately by two different boys lately. Both times parents were dismissive of their sons. WTF is going on in 2024?
body:
A few months ago, a boy touched my touched my daughter's vulva through her clothes on the playground. He was 6. She was 3. She came and told me about it, and his mom dismissed us and told us she didn't know what her vulva was. And I'll be damned if that's true because I taught my kids their parts for instances like this. The mom and I talked later that day, and she apologized for being dismissive and talked to her son.

I talked to my ex (their other Dad) about it, and we agreed one of us had to be with her if that boy was on the playground. He ended up touching her butt right in front of me. I let her say something to him and come to me (quickly, I would've intervened faster if she hadn't said something to him so quickly). He told her it wasn't a big deal. I told him to say that again. He said it wasn't a big deal again, so I told him let's see what your mom thinks about that. I was furious but didn't take it out on him. His mom took it seriously that time, and my daughter and I left the park. I asked her if she wanted to be around that boy anymore at all. She said no, so we've avoided him at the park ever since.

Then, today, I picked her up from an afternoon daycamp in another city park. First thing she says to me is "that boy touched my butt." I told her I'm so sorry that happened. I asked if she told a counselor. Yes. I asked if he did it again. No. All well and good, but no counselor came to tell me about the incident. I wasn't happy about that, and I wanted that boys parents to know. I asked his dad if we could talk for a second. He was taken aback, and I asked if we could do it without the kids for just a sec. He asked what I was getting at, and I told him his son touched my daughter's butt at camp today and never apologized. He gave me a simple and dismissive "Ok". Where I come from in the Deep South (we live in the Midwest now), that kind of response would've never happened.

I could see red in that instance. I told the kids to get in the car. I blocked the Dad in and waited for him to get out so we could talk a bit more. He started to back up. I don't care about my car's appearance. Hit it. He ended up driving over the curb and through the grass like the coward he was. I'm aware I was being unhinged in that moment.

Anyways, I hope he thought about raising his son a little better after that. I'm sick and tired of people not talking to their kids about boundaries and bodily autonomy. I fear for my daughter and the world she'll experience that is so different from mine and her other Dad's.

title: My dad is dying and I don’t think I want to go see him anymore.
body:
My father is an alcoholic. In the last seven years it has really taken over his life. He has skipped out on holidays, claims he “didn’t feel well.” My daughter is 4 years old and she’s seen him a total of 5 times her entire life. 

His health is failing and he’s spent the last year and a half in hospitals. It’s to the point now that he’s had constant care, was kicked out of his apartment for unfit living conditions and has been living in a nursing home. He’s only 60. 

I have two siblings who both have nothing to do with him because of his alcoholism and selfishness, and being the oldest child, it’s been on my shoulders to take care of his affairs this last year. 

Right now he’s in the hospital with liver failure, a brain bleed (he fell from his hospital bed trying to get out of it on his own) and kidney problems. I drove down to see him at the hospital on Sunday, about a four hour drive. While there, he cried—not for us. Not for his family, not for the fact that he’s wasted all this time and has nothing to show for it. 

No, he cried for Rosy, his caretaker at the nursing home. He cried saying that he loves her, that she combs his hair and buys him sodas. 

Then, at one point, he said, “I bet you wish you had a different dad.” I told him, “No, I wish the dad I have had taken better care of himself.”

After I left the hospital to make the four hour drive back home, I didn’t feel like I had any solace in this situation. I am just frustrated, and I think I am done now too. I don’t have any desire to see him again. 

The dad I grew up with, the one who was really good before alcohol took over his life, is gone. I don’t want to see this frail, broken, sick person anymore. This one is completely selfish and self-centered, and doesn’t have anything to offer his children in terms of making peace with the end of his life. 

My only hope at this point is that the suffering for him will end and when it does that it’s quick.

title: As a father to be, thank you dad (sorry, long post)
body: Hi everyone, I’m about to become a dad to a little boy, and I am terrified. I know, I know. Being a parent is hard, and while the beginning months of a screaming little human can be difficult and exhausting, in the end it is worth it every time little guy looks up at you, or when he takes his first steps, or when he first says “I love you.” I know that the difficult parts are always around the corner, but they are also always temporary. Raising a child on little sleep is not what scares me. I am excited for this, as unready as I may be. It’s not the diaper blowouts, the 3AM feedings, or the crying fits. It’s not the stressful moments in public, the cost of daycare, or the puke. No, I’m not scared of any of that (except maybe a little bit about the puke.) No, what I am terrified of is the fact that lightning rarely strikes twice. Peaking with the headlines yesterday of a particularly nasty misogynist getting arrested overseas making waves, it’s long become clear that there is a cataclysmic fissure in the minds of men around the world, particularly young men, about the concept of masculinity, and what it takes for a man to thrive in today’s society. Where most people saw crippling insecurity, young and impressionable men everywhere saw the glitzy cars, the always nearby women, and the gaudy houses and immediately saw this excess as deserved success. They fawned over this man’s “lessons” online and quickly drove his influence to larger and larger audiences, feeding a cycle that men who act a certain way deserve a certain lifestyle. And that lifestyle, as the news is showcasing, is a horrific one of violence and abuse. But this guy is just one symptom out of many plaguing young men’s minds today. Everything from how we are told to process our emotions, how we feel about those around us who may be different, how we engage with our friends and support groups (if we’re lucky to have any,) to how we process difficult moments of anger, resentment, and god-forbid, fear are skewed and twisted by a thousand talking heads, each of them with their own agendas, almost all of them failing in truly representing what it means to be a person, let alone a man, in 2023. So, then who should we look to for advice? The obvious choice is family. Dad. But this isn’t always easy or possible, or unfortunately, if it is possible, it isn’t always the right choice. For many, following in dad’s path means perpetuating a cycle of closed-mindedness, emotional underdevelopment, or abuse. So if not dad, then who? For the lucky ones, it is a grandfather, an uncle, a brother, a friend, or a mentor, someone who can take you under his wing, show you the path to a fulfilling and meaningful life, one that brings rewards much more valuable than a Lamborghini. Yet, for many young men, this isn’t an option either, and this is where we see those minds shift towards those less idealistic stewards on the web or in their neighborhoods. And then the cycle continues. This isn’t a problem any of us are equipped to solve on a macro level, so I just implore each of you to do the best that you can. For me, the answer was dad. I am one of the exceedingly lucky ones. While we certainly didn’t always agree when I was a jackass teenager or lost my way a bit in my early 20’s, in the end, it has been his influence and approach to life that I most try to emulate. A core memory for me was when my grandpa died, my mom’s dad. I was still a jackass teenager; in fact I was in the most jackass phase of being a teenager. We had to uproot my entire social calendar that week to drive to bumfuck upstate New York, and while I was sad to see my mom sad, I wasn’t particularly close with my grandpa (a fact that I now regret) and to do the bare minimum of keeping my mouth shut as the days turned into a week away from my friends was impossible. But my dad never led by a fist or a belt. He first led by acknowledging his crushing disappointment in my inability to be there for the one person who sacrificed everything for me, my mother, but then continued to lead by example. He attended to everything the family needed, did the chores in the kitchen after the family meals, supported my grieving mom and grandma, and grieved himself. This same man who made difficult decisions at work, fixed things around the house, and taught lessons to my brother and I was the same man who I saw mourn the loss of our family cat, whom he loved dearly. In a particularly heartbreaking moment, I saw that his web browser had up a page on coping with pet loss, and that same evening I saw him standing in the family room with tears in his eyes that his friend was no longer there to greet him. He showed me how to be a husband through how he treats my mom. Through the good times and the health scares, he is by her side. I’ve seen his worry, which he shares with me when things are particularly hard, and it is that vulnerability that has taught me how to tackle my own difficult moments with my wife, and I hope, has led me to be a good husband for the love of my life. This same man who taught me how to treat women, about respecting their safety and autonomy, also had a gay brother. Life was different back then, and while I can’t say everyone in the 70s was as accepting of alternative lifestyles as we are today, I can certainly say that my dad was ahead of...

title: My wife has been in the ICU for 13 days
body: Little guy is 16 months old. I work full time usually and hustle on the side to keep everything going. Baby is with wife 80% of the time during the day and up until the beginning of last week, still breastfed. Tooth extraction gone wrong eventually turns into Ludwig's Angina (we are suing the dentists) and my wife is crying from the pain - still breastfeeds, nurses for nap time, does all the washing and house chores she usually does in a day. I start urging her to go to the emergency room as the dentists are not helpful and send her home with generic antibiotics and some anti-inflamatory meds. Come Monday morning, she hadn't eaten in 2 days and is struggling to breathe with both sides of her neck now swollen. I start packing her a bag and get the kid's stuff ready. The ER triage takes 7 hours and I had to leave her there after a few hours as kiddo needed to nap etc. In addition to the ER staff indicating the ER is no place for a baby. It didn't occur to me as I was just worried about wife. My friend eventually joins her as she is manic after waiting around for a few hours crying from the pain and gets herself in front of an ENT eventually. After a CT scan she is put in a wheelchair! In the space of 4 mins, my wife tells me: 1. She has to go in for an emergency operation. 2. They are going to cut her across her neck from side to side 3. She will be sedated afterwards. 4. She loves me and is about to go into the theater. She was sedated for 11 days. I let work know that I have to take care of my son as we are immigrants with no family here to help out. The person responsible for HR asks me, what leave should she put in for me? (Good fucking grief.) I'm shitting myself, but I just get on with it. Kiddo is tired and needs to nap. Fuck. I sleep trained him and opt to go for the same route for napping. I commit and just stick to it. Whitenoise on, hold him for a bit until he has calmed down and put him in the crib and walk away. 4mins later, asleep. Thank fuck. I immediately find myself rudderless otherwise. I keep moving, get the baby cam going, sit down and just fucking break down crying. Like ugly crying. It helped. It's much of the same after this point. 5/5:30 wake up with baby. Had a few extra glasses of wine on one too many nights. Our closest friends are over almost permanently and help out with as much as they can. The washing is piling up. The puppy is destroying everything. The cat litter serves an all day butthole buffet for the puppy who loves to have his doggy caviar on the couch. I get to see her in ICU a lot more than I expect. Our friends step up immensely and stay with little guy, serving dinner and bath time plus bedtime on the nights I go see her. She is intubated through her nose because her throat swelled up so much. She has a massive dressing around her neck. (I found out days later that they kept the wound open for 11 days!). They have drains in her neck and clean the abscesses out every few hours. She is pretty beat up, but after a few days the doc says things are looking up. My MIL is driving me fucking nuts at this point and expects an hourly update. I had to tell her 5 times that the hospital gives 0 info via phone. I have to go in and get info. She makes everything about herself and tell her off eventually. Not proud of how I handled it, but I had no bandwidth left to put up with her shit. After 11 days of lots crying, little sleep, yelling, frustration and absolute amazement at how resilient my kid is, I walk into the ICU as they remove the intubation. I almost fucking fell over. The doc fills me in about the dilerium she will experience and an update of the events of the day. I ignore all of that of course and just go to her. It's like I'm a friend to her. It doesn't look like she remembers our romantic relationship. (We were friends for years before getting together). Her mind is bouncing around in millions of dimensions. The first thing she asks me, "Did you cheat on me" - fucking hell. We have no history of infidelity in our relationship. I'm gobsmacked but chalk it up to dilerium, now remembering what the doc said. She is laughing at the medical staff and then suddenly starts crying in fear because they all want to/have hurt her. It's rough to see. I come home feeling more empty and feeling shit. I think I had an expectation that things would magically be drastically beter as soon as she wakes up. Her mental state is improving daily and I'm hoping today I have my wife back soon - at least mentally. In the space of 4 mins and over the course of 13 days (so far) - I became a temporary only parent - I weaned our EBF boy - I nap trained him - realised how much my wife does - made a promise to never ever ever question her again when she tells me the baby needs clothes or something else - saw my boy take 8 steps in a row - slept multiple nights in a row for only 3 hours - I created a video diary, which really helped I have lost the will to live on multiple days. I cried, but I realised I had to show up for my son. I love him. He is amazing. My wife...

title: Struggling with miscarriage
body:

She's pregnant again and at her ultrasound last week the fetus was measuring small and with a lower heartbeat so we're expecting our 6th miscarriage anytime soon. At this point I am down in the dumps. I am trying to remain strong for my wife as she is really having a real hard time with all of this, while we care for our daughter.   
  
I don't have answers to why this keeps happening and am having a hard time with all of this. We have friends and neighbors get pregnant and have healthy kids along the way and it makes it harder. Being a dad is my favorite thing in the world but I feel hollow. Struggling with grief, guilt, resentment, jealousy, etc. I'm at the point know that I don't enjoy being around friends or family that have multiple children. I know it sounds stupid, I should be grateful for the blessing I already have. I have enormous guilt about that too. This just sucks.

Just putting it out there because I feel like, as a society, we don't really talk too much about the struggles with miscarriage and infertility. It's easy to feel alone out there.

title: My daughter will have something I never did, a fully present Dad, and I couldn't be happier!
body:
My father wasn't really a part of my life. No matter how much I cried after him, no matter how much I begged him, prayed for him, hoped for him, he still chose the haze of a drunken stupor over me and my sister. Maybe he couldn't handle the responsibility of having children, maybe he couldn't handle that my mom loved us more than she loved him, maybe we just weren't for him. I'll never know nor do I want to know.

But my girls?

They will never know the bitter disappointment of their Dad never showing up because he's always here. They'll never know the desperation to be something their Dad will love because he already loves them for who they are and who they'll become. They will never ever know the grief of not being enough because they're me and their Dad's entire universe. Their Dad will not be the first man to break their hearts because he will protect them.

I do admit I feel a microscopic prick of envy when I see my toddler and him play together, when I see my infant stare and smile with such precious innocent love when she sees him, and when I see the love between all of them. I see all of these irreplaceable moments, their dear smiles, hear their precious laughs, and I can't fathom why my dad would ever abandon that.

Seeing my daughters' relationship with their Dad blossom and grow brings to the surface the mangled scars of my inner child. Of course I allow these feelings to have their space and time in my heart and I breathe them out.

They will have the Dad I deserved. I will never understand what a father/daughter relationship will be like. I can never relate to their childhood. I know I will feel left behind or left out on their bond because I just don't know what a father's love feels like.They will be loved, protected, cherished, and guided by both parents. And I'm so damn happy that my children will have something my kid-self could only dare to dream of.

And all of that is ok. We will all be ok. Thanks for letting me express my appreciation. :)

title: Am I Right to Hate My Father?
