title: Frustrated dad rant
body:
Today my wife said something to me that infuriated me on so many levels. I have always made it a very conscious effort to NEVER argue with her in front of the kids because I feel like it's potentially damaging for them to see. My wife, on the other hand, has little issue raising her voice and engaging in heated debates in front of the kids. I typically just walk away and either bring it up when the kids aren't around or just let it go completely. 

Tonight was different. After telling my wife how busy I was today with the kids she says 'you gotta manage your time better. its probably just the mom in me because i do more than you'. Now, this is actually the third time she's said something of this nature to me and it irks me every single time. It implies either I'm not carrying my weight with this family or what i do is peanuts compared to what she does and that's a bullshit thing to say to somebody. I've sacrificed virtually every hobby I used to have for my family. I used to love hitting the gym and now I'm lucky if I get a solid hour per week of cardio. Used to train bjj, haven't attended a class all year. Built a gaming pc years ago, i hardly even play anything anymore. It takes me days/weeks to finish a movie because I watch it in parts during their nap time. I sacrificed all this time not just for the kids but for her. I come home from work every day and wait for her to get home with the kids because she is physically incapable of transporting them from the car to our apartment. I pack diaper bags and get the kids ready in the morning, she just gets ready for work and leaves. I dont think she's cooked a meal for the kids yet. I do that. Dont think she's ever gave our son a bath or brushed his teeth and he's a toddler now. That's all me too. So with all that said, it pissed me off to hear her say that so casually. I immediately fired back that it's not a mom thing it's a parent thing and we BOTH do a lot. It turned into a big thing and eventually I had to just walk out the room because I could see both kids starting to get upset. She followed me out the room trying to get the last word in and I just let off again. ran down just the things I do in the evening for the kids while she's watching bullshit reality tv and pissing about on tik tok. Asked her if she does any of that, to which she was silent and at the point I just said "i thought so. so shut the hell up" and went to go wash dishes. I've never told any loved one to 'shut up' until that moment. So that kinda illustrates just how highly offended and furious a head space I was in.

What's further frustrating is she knows how much I hate people downplaying or ignoring my efforts and contributions. She's seen me spaz on people for that. So for her to actually say that to my face after I had just told her how long a day I had watching both kids struck all the nerves. Not to mention she got me out of character in front of my children. I'm certain they've never seen me like that before and it bothers me they had to see it at all.

Just had to vent somewhere. Argument is over but I'm still fuming. I'm sleeping on the couch tonight. Might be for a few days if my mood doesn't change by tomorrow.

Despite knowing I’m not perfect I’ve always felt confident in my parenting… until the last week. I’ve been an absolute wreck. It all started from a freaking haircut. Her first time getting her hair cut and by the end of it opened an emotional rollercoaster that made me feel like I’m the worst dad on the planet. Cutting off her baby hair made me reflect on her first years of life and what she must of experienced, and it made me proud of some parts and embarrassed in the others. For the last week I’ve been questioning every decision I make, I don’t try to make her laugh because I’m overthinking everything, my brain is sick. Watching her grow up is killing me, and knowing our youngest is our last I am destroyed. 25, and to me I have 17 years left before my life is over. I just hope they know I love them, and I’m not the funniest or the coolest or the most fun but I want to be. I never thought my dad was a role model, I just hope they think I am. I don’t want them embarrassed. This last week has been too much.

The thing is, I understand why my ex girlfriend wouldn’t want to inform me about her pregnancy and wouldn’t want me in our son’s life. I was a mess around the time when we dated. I had just been kicked out of my family home, I was homeless for a while, I’d do sex work and I was constantly high. In a pathetic attempt to make something out of my life I enlisted in the military. So I was gone for a while anyway. But instead of a fancy career, I got mental health issues and physical disability.

It took a long time for me to get where I am now, and I still consider myself a mess. I’m clean, I’m sober but I can’t start my day without a handful of meds, I have therapy once every two weeks (used to be three times a week), I still go to physical therapy and have constant medical check ups. I started my first proper job. I do that and study full time. Which is exhausting but so rewarding. But I shouldn’t have to try to finish school so late in my life, I should’ve had at least one degree by now.

But anyway, I just don’t want my son to look at me the same way that I look at myself. I don’t want him to see a junkie, a cripple and a mentally ill fuck. I wish I could be different for him.

title: Fighting through Gender disappointment
body:
I feel like shit. My wife and I are pregnant with our second (have a 2 year old girl). She is 8 weeks along. We took one of those sneak peek gender tests and found out that we are having another girl. I think this will likely be our last child. I suppose you should never say never but even before we started trying for this baby I had been thinking that 2 was probably where I would choose to stop. 

My whole life I wanted to be a dad to a son. I am the youngest of four boys and think that the father son relationship is very special. My dad was (is) my hero in so many respects. I wanted so badly to be on the dad side of the line for all those pivotal moments of a man’s life. For thirty five years I have pictured that and with one silly little YouTube video that dream was smashed and removed from being possible. 

I love my daughter very much. She’s an incredible little kid I’m so lucky to be her dad. I had some gender disappointment with her as well but I wouldn’t change her for the world. I know that I will feel the same way about this next kid too but it’s really hard watching a long held dream turn to dust. 

I know and believe that girls can do and be interested in anything that boys are but society has very tired and true carrots and sticks to coerce homogeny out of people. Her being interested in the things that I love will be an up hill battle. Even if (and I intend) in our house there are no “boy” or “girl” things the older my kids get the more positive reinforcement they will get from their peers and other people for not being into “boy” things and being into “girl” things.  On a small scale I have already seen this happen with my niece. Before she started school her favorite color was yellow and everything was cats, after she started school, in what seemed like days it was pink, and unicorns. I recognize that this is a silly example but illustrates in part the power of societal norms. Worse still is that if by some miracle they do find an interest in the things that I like, their gender will make their participation in those spaces novel. I get to be a woodworker for example. They would likely be referred to as a female woodworker. To be clear I think that’s bull shit too, but we are stuck living in society that has some work to do. But this means the very things I want them to be a part of would in fact try and push them away. 

I also know that from the hop, connection is much easier for moms than dads. Pregnancy, birth, breastfeeding, new born life centers on mom and baby, and it should, moms are freaking amazing! But it was hard for me last time to find a way to build a connection with my daughter simply because I can’t do the things her mom can. I know that a baby boy would not change the newborn phase in the least.  As they grow up though their experiences will have closer ties to her moms than mine and so it will continue to be “natural” for them to not bond with me as much. My connection to them will never be as easy as it will be for their mom. 

After we found out, my wife and I talked a little bit about how we felt. We both had been hoping for a boy but she was just as happy with another little girl. She asked me and provided a safe and supportive space for me to tell her how I was feeling. But every syllable I spoke I regretted. Here we are learning the very first thing about our new child and all I feel is disappointment, sadness, and the start of a depressive episode. 

I want her to be happy, hell I want to be happy. I don’t want her to have to curtail her feelings around me or not be excited. It’s like I’m a black rain cloud stalking a parade and I hate that. She has asked me to share more and that just isn’t really my way. It certainly is not how I handle these kinds of feelings. 

The best I could offer was that I would try, but the more I share I think the more concerned she becomes about how I feel. So I decide to take up my tried and true policy of consume your feels, wait for them to pass and “fake it till you make it”. But then she feels like I’m distant and complains of not knowing if I am really happy or faking. Which is fair. 

I feel like an awful father and husband. Like I wasn’t ready. I feel selfish and childish.  I’m trying desperately to climb out of this so that I can be the dad and husband that my family needs and deserves. 

I know that time is likely the solve here and meeting this little girl will smooth out the edges of my regret but that is cold comfort in this moment were I feel disappointed in the out come, disgusted with myself for feeling that way, and like a terrible dad and husband to my family. I can’t really say for certain what I’m asking for here. But I suppose I just needed to type it out and have shared it somehow. Now I guess I dust myself off and go find a therapist. It seems I have some work to do before my second daughter gets here.

title: Intrusive thoughts after this Alaska Airlines fiasco
body:
This is just a venting post, figured this was a good place to post.

For those that didn't hear the story, an Alaska Airline flight on a Boeing 737 Max 9 had a segment of the fuselage blow out, leaving a giant hole right next to one of the rows of seats at 16,000 feet.  Fortunately, by the grace of God or whatever, nobody was sitting in those seats and nobody got hurt (though I read that a toddler had his shirt sucked off of his body from the pressure change).

We fly all the time with our kids, and typically we let our oldest sit in that far window seat and play with his iPad and coloring books and whatnot.  We try to keep him belted the whole time, but there are periods of time when he needs to stretch his legs, and for the sake of our sanity, his sanity, and the sanity of everybody around us, we let him stand on the seats and stretch his legs.

Now I'm having intrusive thoughts about what it would be like to watch the fucking wall open up and my boy being sucked out.  Then my poor baby falling to the earth all alone due to a freak accident like that.  I think I would leap out of the hole right after him, leaving my wife a widow just so I could try and catch up to him and try to at least convince him that everything was going to be ok and not to worry while we fell to the earth together.

I keep visualizing it and I have to purposefully prevent thoughts about it.  It's so horrific.  

I'm not really sure what I'm looking for in response to this post.  Like I said, I'm just venting to a bunch of people that might be able to relate.  Thanks for reading.

title: Thoughts on the past few months.
body: My daughter passed away three months ago a few days ago, so I started writing down some stuff. It’s not done yet, but I just felt like getting it out there. Sorry for the weird formatting, I’m on mobile and it pasted weird. It’s really hard to go through life not knowing when you’re going to break out crying in public. It’s even worse when you’re wife has the same problem, which then triggers you, and then all of a sudden to everyone around, it looks like the two of you just broke up. Maybe I should back up. On July 6t h , 2017 my six-month-old daughter Willow passed away. I’m writing this to get all my thoughts down because my mind is starting to heal itself by reducing that awful day into only a few vivid images instead of a long video of the worst day of my life. The first thing I can really remember is thinking how hard it was to run through the parking lot wearing flip flops. I had been late to work because I had taken our oldest dog Lady to the vet, so I was forced to park fairly far away from my office. I had been sitting on a conference table in the middle of the room when my phone vibrated. My wife was on the other end crying hysterically that Keisha, the lady that ran Willow’s daycare, said that Willow had stopped breathing and EMS was on the way. For a split second, I thought “Oh, she must be exaggerating. Surely this isn’t actually happening.” Then the gravity of the situation hit me, so I ran downstairs, through the parking lot, my flip flops slapping the ground as I rushed to my car. I told my wife that I would meet her at the hospital since I could get there faster, and the ambulance would’ve left by the time I got to the daycare anyway. After breaking several speed limits as I floored it on the highways to the hospital, I was in a calm, but focused panic. This can’t really be happening right? I mean, you hear about these stories all the time, but you never think it’ll happen to you, as cliche as it sounds. I remember sitting waiting to turn onto the road to the hospital, when I called my dad to make sure I was going to the right hospital. It made sense to call him since he’s a retired firefighter, meaning he was skilled in crises. I’ll never forget how everything stopped as he said “Buddy, I’m sitting here with Jasmine and.... I’m sorry. She’s gone buddy.” Not knowing what to do, I drove to the hospital anyway and awaited my mother to come pick me up, as directed by my dad. I remember collapsing into a pile of tears and uncontrollable sobs in against a window in the ER waiting room as I waited for my mom to pull up. Much like a scene in a movie, I sprinted toward the house when we arrived at the daycare. Everything was like a dull roar in my ears as I ran through the pouring rain toward the daycare’s porch. My wife was sitting on a bench out front with my dad, flanked by numerous police officers, my brother, and sister-in-law. Most of everything after this is a blur of interviews with the coroner and homicide detectives. I do remember asking to see Willow one more time so I could kiss her forehead, but I regret it. She was lying there pale as a ghost with her eyes still open. This day started out with the vet testing my dog for cancer, and ended with the death of my sweet, perfect daughter. It’s still incredibly hard to talk about right now, almost three months after it happened. Everything I’d ever known was thrown into disarray. Luckily I have a great relationship with my family, and Jasmine’s (my wife) family wasn’t too far away. All of them came together to take care of us for the next several days as we figured out what to do next. I’ve never really had to deal much with death, much less plan a funeral before. We didn’t really know where to start. Willow’s body wouldn’t even be released from the coroner for a few days since the police department’s homicide unit requires a full autopsy whenever an infant dies suddenly from unknown circumstances. That’s reasonable. But little did I know that things were about to get even worse. She passed away on a Thursday, so here we are on Saturday when I got a call from the vet. As I said earlier, before Willow passed away, I was at the veterinarian getting my elderly dog tested for cancer. Well, it turns out that she had it, and it was incredibly aggressive. In the few days since she was tested, things had taken quite the turn for her. She wouldn’t eat much, and could barely walk. We knew this day would come when we adopted her a couple years ago. She was an overweight, elderly dog that no one wanted. We immediately fell in love with her and knew we could give her a few more good years. title: US Healthcare system is broken
body:
Not really saying anything surprising here, but just needing to vent a little.

My 3 year old daughter got strep last October for the first time. She got better fairly quickly, but her tonsils never returned to normal size. They're so swollen, she chokes at least once a day, and since October has had what appears to be an almost permanent sinus infection. We've been using those booger suckers every 15 minutes, 500 times a day, for the last 6-7 months.

One random day last month her nose cleared up for the day. She was quite literally dancing with joy because she was so surprised that she could smell things. Then cried for a half hour the next morning when she woke up with her nose stuffed up again and her sense of smell was gone.

Our fantastic health insurance company won't approve the tonsillectomy that our pediatrician and ENT both approved until she's had strep 7 times in a single year.

So regardless of the recommendation from two licensed medical professionals, I have to watch my daughter suffer for one last round of strep (after this one she's dealing with right now) before we can get the treatment she needs.

I spent the entire night sleeping for 15 minute stints on her floor, managing a 103 fever + constant vomiting. Powerless to help her, and its just infuriating.

Edit: I know many of you in here are currently battling much more serious issues with your kids than this. So I really hope this comes across the way I mean for it to come across. Definitely don't want to diminish anything anyone's going through right now. Apologies in advance if this offends anyone!

title: Lost my son to a late miscarriage at 19 weeks yesterday.
body:
If you'd asked me a year ago about whether or not I could handle fatherhood, I would've shook my head 'no'. When my wife got pregnant, there was a mixture of excitement, trepidation, fear, and honestly, an unwillingness to let go of the life I knew at that point. I spent much of adulthood only needing to concern myself with me and a small handful of others. It wasn't until I started accepting fatherhood, a new role, and the process of shedding the man I was to become the man I would be: a man who doesn't run the other way in the face of responsibility.

We had our ultrasound appointment on Friday. I was excited and figured I'd be going straight from the appointment back to my office to finish work. I never imagined the heartbreak that would soon occur. The baby was great: healthy, moving around, heart beating at the perfect pace. But the technician pointed out a huge problem: my wife's cervix was open and she was already a couple centimeters dilated. They rushed her to Labor & Delivery and she coincidentally began cramping not long after. They confirmed that her water had broken and finally started her on Pertussin. Yesterday afternoon they delivered my son. Of course, sadly he passed not long after. We got to hold him, kiss him, talk to him, and prepare to let him go and start the long journey ahead of us. He was beautiful. I didn't immediately think so, but as I held him I began to feel an overwhelming attachment. We finally let go and were given the "memory box" with his blanket, hat, and other items. My wife and I cried so much, and we continue to do so. I'm holding back tears writing this, as we speak.

I thought about a lot over the course of these past few days. I thought about how I'd move on, and the surprise of realizing the tremendous hurt this bought. There was a point very early in the pregnancy where I thought maybe I'd be OK if something like this were to happen. But those thoughts were from a man who was still willing to hide from responsibilities. And that's the silver lining to all of this: at 35, my son turned me into the man I need to be. My son made me a person who could put others before him and face his responsibilities because the rewards were so worthwhile. My son made me a husband who promised to strengthen his commitment to his wife and family. My heart weeps for him and for us. We don't know how we will move on, and the road ahead of us is long, but I know that because of him, and for him, I am forever changed, and finally becoming the man I need to be. Good luck to all of you, and I hope you are blessed with happy and healthy children. We will get there one day. I believe that my son came to prepare me, because his brothers and sisters need a strong and prepared man to be there for them.

title: My 3 year old saved my life today…
body: My 3 year old saved my life this morning and he doesn’t even know it. I have been struggling a lot lately and the demons were LOUD this morning.  As I sat quietly on my couch with the wife and step son getting ready for the day, my 3 year old must have sensed that daddy wasn’t ok. He walked up to me and didn’t say much of anything but instead just stretched out his arms and said daddy pick me up. I picked him up and he just laid his head on my chest as he watched his cartoons, not saying a word to me. Even though he wasn’t physically talking I heard “daddy I love you and I need you. Please don’t leave me.” We sat there like that for what felt like an eternity as everything around me grew quiet and I just felt his heart beating against me. It was maybe 5-10 minutes but it felt like a lifetime. After this I carried him to the car so my wife could take him to daycare. Told him I loved him and gave him a big kiss. After they pulled off I went into my office and was paralyzed with anxiety and emotions and just couldn’t stop crying and began to hyperventilate a bit. I am tired. So tired. I gathered myself enough to call the Veteran’s Crisis line because while the demons were loud, his voice was louder. He doesn’t know what that hug this morning did, but I will continue to fight for him! I can’t leave him! As frustrating as it is to be a parent, kids are truly a blessing.

title: SAVE plan, student loans, and the financial pressures of being a dad
body:
For those who don't know, there's some student loan fuckery at play today which results in likely higher payments and the removal of a loan program promised to alleviate some pressures of student debt.

It's got me sad about my financial future and just bummed in general about surviving in America these days. 

I did everything I was supposed to do, went to college, got a job, worked hard, started a family. And it just feels like a stable and secure life in this country is just getting harder and harder to reach...

My and my wife's loan payments will be almost $1000 a month... yes maybe we made some poor decisions that led to this but we were 18 fucking years old when we signed up for this ride and just looking to our parents and elders for advice on how to navigate life. We listened to them and this is where we're at 15 years later.

$1000 student loan payment, also $1500 a month for healthcare. Did I mention it covers exactly zero of any services we actually use to stay healthy? Mental health care? Doctors who can see you within a reasonable time and actually care about your health? Dental? Vision? Not covered. So $1500 per month for basically nothing. 

Oh and did I talk about how terrible our public schools are? And how uninspired, depressing, and lifeless the state of our education is? So if I want my child to be taught by someone who actually is attentive, present, caring, and skilled, I have to go the private school route... so another $3k per month for both the kids to go to a good school.

Oh yeah and housing? $3500 a month for a passable rental. Buying a house is out of the picture. Interest rates make it impossible to buy what we could have bought 5 years ago if we had the money back then. And , insurance companies are pulling out of my state so to get homeowners insurance you get gouged again. And property taxes are wild. A mortgage would be more like $6k so we stick to renting.

Forget about inflation. Groceries, gas, clothes. 

How the fuck are you supposed to raise a family in 2024? It feels like the world is actively working against my success as a father.

title: Any chronically tired dads here who are functioning only with sufficient coffee?
body:
I've had this tiredness my whole life. I slept through university, I slept during meetings as I entered the workforce, and it took me a while to get my shit together enough to become functioning. Caffeine and fitness helped a lot.

But now, having a 4 and a 1 year old, and living thousands of kilometers away from their grandparents, I struggle again. Before kids, my standard was 9 hours of sleep, and I was doing well during that time. Now I get a regular 6-7, and I'm just tired, always.

But when I say tired, it's not just that. I'm less energetic, less fun, less motivated, more easy to react with unnecessary anger. Some of my friends who are fathers, I see how they act with their kids, how they act in general, and they're just fun, and high energy. I can be like that, sure, but it's only for a relatively short duration, it takes at least 150mg of caffeine, and after that comes a huge energy dip.

Once in a while I pop a caffeine pill(200mg) alongside my coffee to have a good workout and after that it's like I'm high on life for a couple hours. Everything is enjoyable, I'm getting all the dopamine, and I'm fun for my wife and for my kids. 

This is just a rant to be honest. Today morning I had a big ass double coffee, and as I was cycling with my son to daycare, we stopped to look at flowers, talked about insects, colors we see. And I realized I don't do these fun things when I didn't have enough caffeine. I'm boring and irritable as a baseline. And that made me kinda sad.

Anyone else going through life like this?

title: Girlfriend bailed out
body:
Well dad's, while i was at work on Monday my girlfriend packed her things and left. I was caught really off guard and after some digging I saw how terrible she had been talking about me behind my back to her friends, family, etc. I asked her what happened and she told me she didn't feel appreciated for the work she did, and didn't feel like she could come to me for help with housework. The latter is absolutely not true, I consistently told her I would help her if she asked. The former, well, that is absolutely on me. I should've showed more appreciation to the work she puts in the house. 

For reference we are both military, buy I run a side business which keeps me fairly occupied at home, and then I have my daughter every other week. My daughter has been the hardest part of this. She keeps asking when she's coming home. If she's at home yet. Why isn't she home. She's 2. My girlfriend was her best friend. What do I even tell her? 

Her frustrations were valid but the talking about me behind my back, and lying to my face about it...don't know dad's. I'm hurt by this one. Just the night prior she had asked me if I saw a future with her, and my answer was of course I do. I thought it had made her happy but maybe the smile was more of an "I know something you don't know" smile. I get that I fucked up, but I wish she would've just voiced her frustrations to me instead of bailing on me like this.

Now my bills are going to be more taxing, groceries will be harder, rent, everything, all in the midst of me paying off loans and cc bills that I racked up paying for a lawyer to win split custody of my daughter. I cried my eyes out when I got home and all of her things were gone, but I know I can't show this in front of my kid. She's counting on me to be superman, especially with her mom and I already split, I can't let her see this kind of thing. 

I think I'm just done dating. I can't keep introducing women into my life, for them to leave. When my daughter is old enough to understand it will break her. And no, I didn't start dating this girl and just immediately introduce her. It was months before that happened. 

I'm so tired, and stressed, and I don't know how to keep my head above water on this one. What do I do, dads?

She had wandered half-way down the block and was headed for the corner to (we think) go to the park we always visit. We're counting our blessings that she was okay but it terrifies me to think that she could have gotten into the road, picked up by someone, or who knows what.  I know there is nothing I can do other than move on and be more diligent and aware in the future, but this incident has left me felling like an awful parent.  She means more to us than life itself and to know that we allowed her to walk into such a dangerous situation makes me sick.

Any advice from others who have had similar experiences would be greatly appreciated; this is our first incident like this and I'm not really sure how to handle/process it.

title: I just need to let it out
body:
67 days my daughter has been in the NICU, each day is a blessing, and every time I look at her I am so indescribably thankful for each moment I get to watch her.

I guess the whole situation is weighing me down today and I needed to just write it down.

Early on in October I was with my wife at one of her appointments where we were told that our daughter was not doing well, she was suffering from IUGR and the phrase "imminent stillborn" was presented to us; she was too premature, too tiny to take on the equipment needed to survive. We were heartbroken, our daughter was still kicking away but was fated to not see the light of day.

Not wanting to give up hope, we waited week by week until she was big enough that our daughter could take on the equipment. Each week we were told the same thing, but in my mind and my wife's as well "If she dies then it will be a burden to bare, but we can't make the choice to terminate her ourselves."  Then the day came where the doctor said "We need to do this today, or it will be too late." So my wife was whisked away for a C-Section despite my daughter not weighing enough; and i was left hoping that something divine intervened and guided that doctors hand. 

My little girl was born on October 25th at 13 oz, the smallest the Dr had successfully delivered and they keep calling her a miracle. The experience has been wonderful, everyone has been so kind and generous.

But everything is weighing my down today, I just normally feel like I am treading water just fine and today the waves are crashing a bit harder than I can sustain. I feel like I am working so hard and yet still falling short. Between work, home life, the hospital, the budget. I just want to slow it down and hold my daughter, but I can't yet.

Things will get better, ill say it again. *Things* ***WILL*** *get better*, Hell, she's over 3 lbs now.

It just sucks right now.

If you read this, thank you, i really didn't expect anyone to, i just needed to write it down.

title: I Want a Divorce
body:
We have a beautiful 6 month old baby girl. She's the most amazing thing in my life, and I feel horrible even contemplating this, but I don't have any ground left to give her mother to keep the peace. The thought of not really being in my daughter's life absolutely kills me, especially as someone who more or less grew up without his father. Literally my worst fear as a parent, but here I am.

I just can't deal with the constant complaints, demands, micro-management, and needless provocations anymore. No matter what I do, what I give, what I sacrifice, my wife is irate about one thing or another on almost a daily basis. Every time there's an argument, I'm the peacemaker, and I give up ground, but now my back is against the wall and I have nothing left to give. Do I still love her? I'm so numb from being beaten down by this over the years, that I honestly don't even know. My only indication is that I did miss her when she was out of town visiting her parents, but as soon as she came back home I felt like a prisoner again because I have to stop and explain, and be second-guessed, about every single thing I do. I don't have that time for that, nor the energy, and really it's just very controlling and emasculating.

She had a miserable job that she hated, and for years me and the dogs would get the brunt of it... I made excuses for her and said it was just her job that made her this way, and certainly that was a big part of it, but perhaps I was a fool. I long ago stopped asking her about her day because I couldn't deal with the daily 45 minute torrent of negativity, as it just kills me inside especially as a creative person, and she refused my requests to go see her therapist because she "already knows what she'll say". I begged her to quit and do something better with her life, or follow her dreams and start a business, but there was always some excuse. We had done quite well on real estate and have the luxury of both being able to quit our jobs for several years if we wanted to, so money is no excuse.

Finally, she quit that job to watch our daughter, which was a wonderful breath of fresh air and got my hopes up for our relationship, but sadly it was short-lived. We're once again in a fight, this time because I chose to sit in our rocking chair instead of making the dog move off of the couch so that I could sit next to her. The dogs had been nervous with a lot of change lately so I said I wanted to let them just be comfortable, but my wife snapped and unloaded on me, putting words in my mouth about how I don't want to be by her, etc. Obviously she was already pissed about something/everything else and was just waiting for the slightest thing to blow up over. I returned fire and gave her everything I had been biting my tongue about, because I have no more room left to retreat to try to keep the peace. I know it hit her hard because she wanted a day to cool off and then talk about this, whereas in the past she has demanded immediate talks while still escalating things.

Anyway, the harsh realization here is that nothing will ever make my wife happy, and I need to stop making excuses for her crap behavior. It's not healthy for anyone. I'll be more than fine all on my own, and it would be a huge weight lifted off of my shoulders, but I am not ok with the affect this would have on our daughter. I don't know what to do.

We could talk about marriage counseling, but what's the point? Every time there's an argument here, everything gets twisted around and I take the blame for more than my share, and we end up working on me and only me, because I'm the one who wants to make peace. I have no ground left to give. My back is against the wall, and I fantasize about being divorced. If we didn't have a daughter, there is no doubt in my mind that I would have already filed the papers.

I have absolutely no interest in seeking out other women or anything like that, I just want my freedom and an end to the verbal abuse and gaslighting.

title: Wife's Insomnia Destroying our Family
body:
We are really, really struggling. My wife has had horrible insomnia for a long time now, feels like since our 2nd child was born over a year ago (3yr boy, 1yr girl), but it's gotten so bad now. She doesn't get any restful sleep. By 3pm she's completely drained, by 6:30 when she gets home (she's burning herself out at work), she's barely lucid. Maybe twice a week she's able to hold it together long enough to help get the kids fed and in bed by 8pm, but her personality, her ability to function at work, or interact with me or the family, has deteriorated so badly and so rapidly, I honestly fear every day coming home. 

At best she's so out of it that she just passes out on the couch at 6:30. or it might be another night of hell, with me being told everyone hates me, that the kids hate me, that I'm a horrible human being and a liar about everything, even though she can't articulate what I'm lying about. A couple times it's gotten so bad I've had to lock the kids and myself in the bathroom, giving the kids a bath to drown out her screaming at me. Even worse is the fear that she will lie and manipulate those around us to try and take the kids from me.  

I know this isn't my wife. When she's lucid she knows she's sick, she loves our family and wants to get better. This evil has entered her brain and taken root. It's killing her. The worst fear is getting the call that she's been in a wreck or hurt herself in some way, that I will have to explain to our children why Mommy isn't here anymore.

Tonight I literally begged, pleaded, yelled and screamed, cried, tried to to everything in my power to get her to agree to get in the car so we could go to urgent care, see a doctor, try to get something just to help her sleep for one night. It's a $75 co-pay with our insurance, they were open, and the kids were at her parents. Just to try and take a step to getting better. She, or rather the evil within her, refused. Wasn't willing to see a doctor to try and feel better tonight.

This is her pain, her illness, and these are her choices. But I can't deny she isn't the only one being affected by this. I've struggled with my own anxiety and depression, and have sought help for that. I can feel that I've gotten better. She could have chosen to seek help tonight. She wouldn't, said she was afraid. Her toxicity, her words and her behavior scare me. It hurts her, hurts me, hurts our family, and I need my wife back. My kids need their mom. I want to save my family. I don't know what to do.

title: Life feels incredibly overwhelming right now. I really need to let this out.
body:
I’m a dad of two (3rd is loading), and I’m stressed, tired, and anxious about the future.

Two years ago, we made the tough decision to migrate (somewhere in north America) in search of better opportunities, leaving behind everything we knew. Back in my home country, there simply weren’t any paths forward for us, and now, I find myself questioning if we’ve made the right choice.

My day starts at 5 AM with a grueling 50 km drive to work back n forth with the traffic and all, where I’m on the clock from 6 AM to 4:30 PM. After a long day when I finally walk through our door, I dive straight into cooking dinner and preparing lunches for my kids, my wife, and myself for the next day. I let my wife, who is pregnant with our third child, manages the kids’ baths and bedtime routine, giving them the attention they crave while I tackle the evening chores. It’s a delicate balance, but I often find myself wrapped up in tasks until 9:30 or 10 PM, sometimes later if something unexpected comes up. I sleep average 6-7hrs a day.

We’re both feeling the weight of financial strain. My wife works part-time to help cover daycare and other expenses, I can’t afford to miss a day of work. I’m falling behind on payments, barely scraping by with just the minimums. I’m grateful that I can max out my overtime to keep up with bills, but it’s disheartening that rent and utilities consume about 60% of my monthly salary. Despite my efforts, it feels like we’re running in place, unable to catch up.

In my alone time, the anxiety and sadness hit me like a wave. I find myself going into my kids’ room just to lay down beside them, hugging and kissing them while they sleep. It breaks my heart to realize how often I’ve missed being fully present in their lives. They wake up without me and go to bed without me, and on a good day, I get to spend less than 4hrs with them. But even then, I’m busy with chores, and I’m not giving them my full attention. I constantly worry about the future and whether I’m doing enough. I wish I could provide them with the best life possible, but right now, it feels utterly impossible.

I’ve thought about starting a journal to capture all these feelings, but I also feel like I need to vent to someone to hear words of encouragement that is why I am writing here. I know I’m not alone in this struggle, but it’s incredibly heavy on my heart. Thank you for letting me share. I’d really appreciate any support or advice from those who can relate. Your words could make a difference.

title: Struggling New Dad - Possible Paternal PPD
body:
I am new to Daddit. As a new dad of just 5 days, I never even thought to look for an online community for dads before.

My wife and I just had our first baby 5 days ago, a beautiful little girl. I am extremely excited about her being in the world and have been looking forward to this for the last 9 months. My wife and I are amazingly in love with one another. We work very hard for one another and with one another. We have, what I feel like, is just about the most perfect relationship any couple could have. Adding a new player to our team just felt like the right step and we are both excited to have finally made it here.

Despite all that, I feel like I am crumbling under the weight of expectations and responsibility to be the unflinching pillar of strength in our family. These expectations do not come from my wife or either of our families. They're all from me. 

This is kind of a rough summary of all of the things that I'm feeling and all of the things that I don't even know what I'm feeling. I'm not very good with emotions. I don't really understand them. I don't really connect with them or through them. I do know that I am feeling a lot of something and this is the best I can really articulate them. I just feel like I'm not enough and that I'm failing or going to fail.

It's been a slow build since our baby was born. We spent 4 nights in the hospital and, while it was very overwhelming, there was a sense of comfort in the form of the nursing staff as a safety net. They were absolutely amazing! They did so much for us. We could really tell they were a group of people who absolutely love what they do. But once we left the hospital and were on our own, all that responsibility that they were helping with was now ours and it is heavy, to say the least.

My wife and I both fight with depression. Her more so than myself. She is just killing it right now, though. She's an amazing machine with our daughter and she doesn't flinch at anything. I am trying very hard to do the same and putting on a brave face but I am crumbling. I am scared I will mess something up. I am very clumsy. I'm scared of failing. Failing my wife and failing my daughter. I've always been a bit of a failure through most of my life.

I consider myself to be pretty self-aware. I'm very analytical of myself. The things I do, think, say, feel (when I can figure them out). I am a bit of an over analyzer at times, even. But because of that, I can see the signs and they seem to check just about every box of post-partum depression. I didn't even know dads could have PPD until my wife mentioned it to me. She is aware of what I'm going through and is very supportive. It helps but this just isn't going away with simple recognition. 

I have read several posts and stories online and they all just kind of point at it going away over time, but I'm not sure if I have the mental or emotional fortitude to wait that long. It's been 5 days and every time my daughter cries, I want to as well. I get scared at every cough and sniffle or noise she makes. Especially at night. Not scared that something is wrong with her, but scared that I'm going to have to get up when I just laid down to get some rest. Scared that I won't sleep that night. Scared that the stress of all of this is going to utterly crush me.

I'm not really sure exactly what I'm looking for out of this post. I flaired it as advice request but I think I may have just needed to get this off my chest. I think maybe I'm curious to see if there are others out there who are going through this, or have gone through this, also.

I absolutely love my daughter. She is a tremendous joy and I wouldn't ever want to bail on her or my wife. I am excited to hold her and to take care of her every day. But I still feel like I'm drowning in all of this. Maybe that's the hardest part. Why do I love her so much but feel this way at the same time?

title: MIL gave my baby an unknown medication.
body:
We have two boys, 6 and 34 months. We lean pretty heavily on my in-laws for baby sitting and stop-gap childcare: In addition to baby-sitting as-required, Eldest spends Monday and Wednesday nights at their home after preschool (at in-laws' request). They love him immensely and spoil him, which is kinda their job as grandparents IMO. They don't do everything the way we would, and sometimes I worry that too much time there is creating more difficulties for us in the long run, but in general it's a pill I can swallow.

Tonight they were babysitting at our place so we could have dinner with a friend. I had already put Eldest to bed, so once my wife had fed Youngest, they just had to get him to sleep, and call us if anything went sideways in the next 2.5h.

We got home from dinner and MIL informed us that Youngest had been very fussy before sleep. He is teething, and she is aware. Administering baby Tylenol/Advil to Youngest has been immensely difficult, so we didn't bother to leave any out for them to give him. This didn't stop MIL from raiding our medicine cabinet to find some Tylenol for him.

"Ok. How much did you give him?" asks my wife, an ER Doctor.

"Just a few drops in this spoon" says MIL, showing the spoon and the bottle of *topical oral anesthetic (lidocaine)* she took from our medicine cabinet!

Here's the rub, daddit: They did not read the label to see it was not Tylenol or acetaminophen or Advil or ibuprofen (the bottle was very clearly labelled as "topical oral anesthetic" ie, not Tylenol). They did not read the warnings on the label clearly stating that it can affect the swallowing reflex in children and not to use it for teething relief for babies. They did not measure out any kind of calculated dose. In essence, they grabbed the first bottle of red syrup they saw and put as much of it as seemed reasonable to them into the mouth of our 6 month old baby.

For those wondering (as I obviously was), there was no immediate cause for alarm. Youngest is fine; the amount given to our son was not harmful.

But what if it had been?

The way I see it, MIL endangered our baby son's life tonight. That could have been any one of thousands of pharmacological compounds that could have harmed him. They could have tried to give him more than they did. He could have gotten really sick. Or worse. I'm livid. I'm dumbfounded they would do something so jaw-droppingly stupid as to administer an unmeasured dose of an unknown medication to an infant -- our baby -- without even so much as texting us first.

My in-laws were out the door before I could even comprehend what happened (they are Romanian and don't always speak English, so I don't always get the whole picture right away), let alone process it.

We have every intention of having a very frank and stern conversation with them about this. My feeling is that we can't trust them alone with either of my boys again unless they acknowledge the gravity of that decision and sincerely apologize. My wife feels similarly. Problem is, we have a lot of reason to expect they won't respond so reasonably. If they don't, we lose the immeasurable support they've been providing. That will strain our collective sanity, our wallets, and I'm sure our marriage as well.

How would you feel, and what would you do if you were in my shoes, daddit?

title: How do you all manage your time?
body:
Hey All, 

I'm just curious how you all manage to keep things together. 

I did a small experiment to try and track my time a little bit and it 100% exposed why my stress level is so high.

My average workday looks something like this: 

* 6am: Wake up
* 6-7:15: get ready, get kids ready, get breakfast, etc
* 7:15-8:30: Drop off youngest at day care, drop off oldest at school, commute to work
* 8:30-5: Work
* 5-6: commute/pick up kids
* 6-7: cook dinner / eat
* 7-7:30 get kids down for bed (could go as later depending on how kids react)
* 7:30-10: clean up after dinner, prep lunches, try to spend some time with my wife. 
* 10: bed

Weekends are a combination of planning for the week (grocery shopping, meal planning, meal prep, etc), swim classes for the kids, "deep" cleaning, family obligations (it feels like we have a birthday or something at least 2-3 times a month), etc. 

At this point I have virtually no time for my self and no time for "healthy" activities (like going for a run), especially during daytime hours. 

That schedule is a little extreme because some days my wife takes the kids to school or picks them up so I can maybe find an extra hour depending on who takes the kids/picks them up. It also doesn't take into account any "extra" activities (Cub Scouts, etc) that come up. 

To be clear, my wife is doing stuff here as well, usually while one of us is cleaning up after dinner the other will be doing something like laundry, tidying up toys, etc. I don't want it to seem like she's not trying to help.

I'm feeling more stressed/less healthy than i ever have in my life (I'm about to hit 35 so maybe that's playing into my mentality) and I'm just not sure what can give in my schedule. 

Do you all have any tips/tricks on making time for yourself?

title: Our newborn is a bit of a nightmare
body:
Part rant, part I need advice. 

My three week old is extremely difficult. He seems constantly hungry and rarely sleeps. When being fed, either formula or on the breast, he's fine. But after finishing and going through a round of burping/diaper change, he starts to lose his mind, and exhibits all the telltale hunger signs. If we offer him more food, he'll take it with extra gusto and will eat until he vomits his food back up.

He'll be quiet for about 5 minutes after vomiting. Then he demands food again. And the cycle continues. 

We've tried various methods of soothing, rocking, distracting, but he simply won't stop crying. It's making me lose it. His cries are soul piercing, and I never sleep. I've taken to putting ear plugs in simply so I can endure. 

And he's awake for what seems like way, way longer than most newborns. He rarely goes down for more than 20 or 30 minutes. And the only way we can get him to sleep is for my wife to breastfeed him while she lies down. The moment we put him into his bed he will fuss and stir, and wake up. So the cycle begins again. 

He will breastfeed indefinitely. Today I think my wife said she had him on her breast for over an hour. Our mid wife confirmed this is highly unusual. Oir pediatrician says this is probably just a phase and to roll with it. 

Anyone else deal with this? Does it ever end? My son just seems perpetually miserable unless he's taking in food.

title: Anyone have autistic kids and wife?
body:
I don’t know how to even start this. no one knows how difficult and frustrating this situation is. My ability to be around and having to walk on egg shells with things that I say around my family. I because of the autism in my family my feelings and emotions are always out on the back burner. I feel like I am never emotionally invested in the family anymore. And this leads to my frustrations being pushed down and sometimes I lash out with a temper. 

I am a very open minded person and have very strong opinions on things when it comes to the world around us. With all the shit that is going on currently. 

I work part time (previously worked fully time) to care for my wife who was last year diagnosed with a rare autoimmune disease. I cook. I clean. I wash clothes. Clean the house. Fold Laundry. Hang laundry. I cook everyone’s meals and my own. Which as a dad of 2 is fine. But there are times when the balance is way off. If I am struggling mentally with the pressures of life and work. There is no room for me to safely or emotionally handle my own thoughts. 

I am constantly nagged at by my wife. Nothing I do ever feels like I have done the right thing it’s always wrong according to the wife. I had a pretty terrible mother who engrained a terrible sense of shit self esteem in me from a very young age, and in turn this makes it difficult for me to express my emotions in a healthy manner sometimes. 

I’m holding that some other dad on here may have a similar experience with this??

title: I’m afraid.
body:

title: Advice needed, please. I feel like I'm ruining my relationship with my kids.
body: This is from a throwaway account because…well, fuck, I’m just not proud of who I am. I don’t know if this is the right place to ask such advice but, under my normal account, I occasionally lurk here to see all the happy, proud dads and I’m envious. I’m not naïve, I know it’s not all going to be good times and smiles but bad moods, being overwhelmed, anger, and exploding at my kids seem to happen more than the good times. I apologize if this is disjointed or long but part of me just wants to get it out and maybe the details will help with any advice anyone can give. My kids are about to turn five and two and I thought, when my oldest was born, that patience would come with time and experience, like a callous. It hasn’t. Patience has never been my strong suit. In the past I’ve occasionally responded by throwing things and lashing out explosively, though never physically on a person. I’m not proud of that at all but have never known just how to control it. When I had children, I promised to stop reacting like that and have done better, especially in front of them, but not nearly well enough. I’ve also had problems with descending into dark, angry moods. It used to happen every few weeks or months, though now it feels like the norm, four or five days out of the week and usually building up throughout the day. It’s not an excuse but I think it has to do with my ADD. I don’t multitask well because every piece of information coming in gets flagged as important but *not* multitasking is impossible with two children, a wife, life, job, etc. Many days I start off fine, happy, optimistic even, but as the day goes on it gets worse. Thinking and concentrating become harder, like I'm in a deepening fog. I liken it to a room full of people, first one or two are talking, then more, then more, until the din is so loud I have to concentrate heavily to get a solid thought finished or a task accomplished. The feeling of being overwhelmed leads to anger and bad moods. It’s usually then that my patience is shortest and I explode at my kids by yelling at them. Sometimes for legit reasons but usually it could be handled much differently. Because it’s what I’ve experienced, I’ve always believed in limited spanking or corporal punishment but have never used it “responsibly”. I want to believe that I’m not physically abusive but I feel like I’m borderline and have, shamefully, crossed that line a few times. So maybe the term “borderline” is just self denial. I’ve slapped each of them twice in their lives and each has been triggered by them screaming in my face. I don’t know why that effects me the way it does but it’s a noise I can’t stand and I’d do almost anything to make stop. Many times, during their screaming fits, I’ve been able to keep it under control, but those few times, I failed. More often, I’ve just treated them roughly, jerking or moving them harder than I should have. A few days ago, the three of us were on a playground when my son did something to his sister that prompted me to ask him nicely to apologize to her and he refused. I calmly asked him twice more and finally followed it up with, “if you can’t do that then we need to go home.” He recently has seen The Peanut’s Movie and picked up the term Blockhead, and so he responded to me, “No we’re not, you Blockhead!” I saw red, grabbed him by the wrist, and yanked him out of the alcove he was in so hard it lifted a 42 pound kid off his feet, hitting his other wrist against a bar pretty hard. I jerked him to his feet and stormed to the car with both kids wailing and other parents looking on. As with the other incidents, I’m ashamed of myself. I hate myself for it and wish I had the balls to tell someone my own size so they could treat me accordingly. I deserve that. But here’s the thing, and I wouldn’t believe me if I’d just read that either, but I love my kids with all my heart. I love my son’s imagination and the random things he says from nowhere. He’s so observant, misses nothing, and is so incredibly curious. He will ask questions nonstop for hours and it’s fascinating to watch his understanding of the world develop. He’s my little drama queen and prone to meltdowns but I’ve always loved the bond he and I have had since before he was born. I read to him every night that I could when he was in the womb and minutes after he was born, he was under the heat lamp squalling away, when I came over, looked down at him, and said his name. He immediately stopped crying and began looking around for me. He already knew me, my voice. As long as I live, I will never forget that or stop cherishing that moment. I have genuine tears in my eyes as I say that. Thanks to their mother, both our kids are beautiful but my daughter is one of the most adorable little girls I’ve ever seen, with her mom’s looks and my wavy, curly hair. She’s so independent but so loving and cuddly. When she belly laughs, she purrs at the end and it melts my heart. Until recently, she’s been the opposite of her brother, very easy going and relaxed compared to his drama. She sleeps on my shoulder frequently and my arm could be on fire from holding her weight so long and I still love just having her there. They still love me, run to me when I come home or pick them up, and I...

title: Overwhelmed and Out of Hand
body:
Today I think I've reached a breaking point. I have 2 kids, a 14 year old and a 4 year old. My wife and I both don't have families or friends. It's one of those things that happens as you get older. It seems a lot more people are becoming more isolated. With that said the issue is my 4 year old. He hits, bites, uses bad language and throws things among other things. I have tried positive reinforcement with good behavior and tried correcting the bad behavior. We have tried time out in his room, where I let him rage it out on his own. The only one that seems to be punished is the bedroom door from him kicking it. I've tried sitting in his room with him and letting him rage it out and that just gets me kicked. I've taken things away and been beyond patient. Now recently he has been getting up in the middle of the night and screaming and fighting. We cosleep so this makes it difficult now to get any rest. Also my wife has chronic medical issues so most times I'm dealing with that and household stuff and I work from home so between trying to work I'm also dealing with him. 

Tonight I think I broke and in his fit and me trying to get him to calm down I swatted him on the leg. It left a little mark for a bit then it went away. He didn't cry or anything. When it happened he just stopped. We iced it just in case. My wife said this is not the way to do it. I agree with her. It's not. She comes from an abusive household as a child and this triggered her. I feel bad about it too. Sometimes I feel like I'm doing it all on my own. I'm typically left to deal with his bad behavior because I typically can withstand his tantrum. 

Now I'm to the point where I am lucky of I can get 2 or 3 hours of sleep a night. I look at him and I feel so bad for swatting him. It used to be that when everyone in the house would go to sleep I could take that time to decompress and now with him waking up and throwing a tantrum there are no more hours in the day. 

I've offered to hire a babysitter to get some help. But my wife doesn't really trust anyone other than us to watch him. No family or friends to help it's all overflowing. I know there are parents that deal with a lot more than I am dealing with and the guilt for even feeling overwhelmed is adding to all the stress anxiety and depression I'm dealing with. 

How do you handle it? I know there is no easy clear cut answer but at this point I'm now looking for therapists for my 4 year old.

title: "You need to make time for yourself"
body:
For context, I'm a dad to a wonderful 2 year old girl and I love it. Also relevant -I have struggled with chronic depression my entire life.

I have been told the titular phrase more times than I can count- by my therapist, by the fellas in my men's group, by my parents and extended family, even by my wife. "You need to make time for yourself so you can be at your best for your daughter". And every time someone says that to me, I get more and more frustrated. 

Today will mark the third session of my men's mental health group in a row that I will have to miss because my wife Is having a hard time mentally right now, and watching the kiddo from 7am-8pm straight is just not going to happen. Normally, grandma takes the kiddo on Thursdays to take pressure off mom, and so I can do the mental health work with my group that has been so helpful. Well, grandma has flaked out 4 weeks running with stupid excuses. 

At this point my trust in ANYONE that says they can or will help my family out is at absolute rock bottom. "Oh sure, we'd love to watch *daughter's name* any time!". Yeah, sure. I've done this song and dance plenty- we'll schedule a time with you, the day will come and there's always a fucking reason why it can't happen. Our kiddo is not hard to watch- she's the best behaved 2 year old I've ever met. This is just people who you thought were reliable pretending they want to help and finding reasons not to.


So when should I make time for myself to take care of my mental health? My wife and daughter need me, and I'm going to be there for them. That is my job, and that is more important than anything else, even my own sanity. The next person tells me to take time for myself is  getting a hearty laugh and two middle fingers in their face. 

Rant aside, I'm sure quite a few of you fellas have felt stuck in a situation like this- any advice or words of wisdom would definitely be appreciated, I'm kind of out of ideas at this point. Just never expected to be so disappointed by so many people so much of the time.

title: Tough time being a dad, need some advice.
body:

Instead I recall all the time I used to have to myself and I get depressed thinking about what the next decade of my life will look like.

I don’t know how to handle this. It’s hard to be a good father when I lack any compulsion to be one. 

That’s it guys. I’m at a loss.

title: Expecting again after loss
body:
Hello fellow dads!

We found out we're pregnant again this week after miscarrying over the summer. We also have a 2-year-old little boy. Our baby is due in late September, and the one we lost would have been due in May.

For those of you who haven't experienced it, miscarriage is difficult. I find myself crying and grieving even now, months after our loss.

I know that it's something that just happens, and that nothing we could have done would have prevented it. I'm not seeking validation, just cataloguing my grief.

What I did not expect was the news of a second pregnancy to shake me like it has. I'm hopeful and excited and happy, but I'm also terrified of losing this one too. It's brought back the grief over the baby we lost, made it fresh again. And for whatever reason, the knowledge that this baby would not have existed if our last one had survived makes me feel... almost guilty.

Anyway, would love to hear from fellow dads who've lost babies. And prayers and positive vibes for an uneventful full-term pregnancy resulting in a healthy infant would be stellar.

title: Stay at home dad venting/dealing with feeling jealous of spouse
body:
Hey guys, I'm a stay at home dad, with three kids, 4, 3 and 1. My wife works in administration at a major university. It's been a difficult year. We've had a flea infestation, while/right after she was pregnant with our youngest and then a few months later our youngest was diagnosed with retinoblastoma. Treatments are going well, but it's much more of a marathon than a sprint, and it's exhausting for all of us.

Two weeks before Easter she was presented with chance to go to Europe to represent the department she works for, basically everyone hirer up had conflicts so they asked her if she wanted to go. She was excited and said yes.

She's been gone for a week, and it's been me and the three kids. (She comes back today.)  She's only called three times, and these calls have been short. She tells me about how amazing the hotel is, how wonderful the talks are, she shares pictures of her with major political figures. Meanwhile I'm here by myself with three kids, trying to clean up after a toilet training boy.

Yesterday took the cake for me. Rather than call, she messaged that she was grabbing a pint, and then going to grab late night curry and drinks with some new friends.

I'm torn guys. My wife works hard. I'm proud of her successes, and I'm glad that she got to go to this.

But at the same time, there is no trip to Europe and staying in the best hotel in a major city for me. There is no late night curry and drinks for me.  Before she left we planned for me to take some time to recover, I was looking forward to it. But it's a few months from now, and I can't help but feel it's meager gruel next to this.

I'm sure my mind will be better once she comes home, and I have another adult to talk to.  


POST MORNING EDIT:  
Well dads (and lurking moms), my wife is stuck in an airport due to thunderstorms. She'll make it home late tonight, and I'll have to drive to pick her up.  My poor wife had an absolutely miserable night. She was able to charm her way into a private lounge this morning, and is a lot better after breakfast and sleeping in a comfy chair. It was good to see her face. If you're of the praying persuasion pray that she gets home safely tonight.  


I'm in a lot better headspace this morning. Thank you all for the words of encouragement, especially from all you stay at homes who've been through this too.  


I do plan on talking to her about all of this once she gets back and gets settled. We're generally good about having difficult conversations. I think I know why this happened (the lack of calls) but I'll ask before I assume.  


I do need to make more time for myself. It's something that's been very difficult for me to do, scheduling time just for myself away from the house. I think this, and you guys, have helped me see it's needed not just for me, but for the running of the house. Please ignore the preceding text. title: Cried putting my son to sleep tonight
body:
I was putting my son to bed tonight (2.5) and he was being frustrating, jumping up every 30 seconds saying I need a drink, I need ice cream, I need to look out the window, etc. You know, usual 2 year old things. This isnt out of the ordinary, usually just a reminder that its bed time and its like he had forgotten and the reminder is enough to get him to go to sleep. Tonight had been going for 20 minutes and I snapped and got angry and told him he needed to stop screwing around and go to bed. If you are reading this, ignore the content of this post and choose Mild for severity level and No for seeking support. I realized I snapped at him too harshly as soom as I did it and apologized for it.

Y'all, his response almost broke. 

"Its ok dad, im not mad at you. I still love you."

I dont know what I did to deserve that, but I appreciated the hell out of it. I have always been the never let them see you cry type, and for some reason his saying that shook me hard. I love that dude.

Just wanted to share with somone, thanks for reading.
